—I address a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to a report in the Daily Telegraph of 4 March on holdups in the construction of the Split Rock Dam. I note that this dam is of considerable significance to the Namoi valley, an area of great production and great potential. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In short, the article in the Daily Telegraph is inaccurate. The background is that on 15 September of last year I announced the allocation for approved projects under the Budget appropriation of some $34.9m under the National Water Resources Program. That was an increase of about 20 per cent. Amongst the allocations for New South Wales under that program was an amount of $1.5m for Split Rock Dam. This was to be provided by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis with expenditure by the New South Wales Government and it followed the provision by the Commonwealth of an amount of $0.5m for the preliminary work on the dam in 1981-82. I understand the New South Wales Government has now accepted the offer, but I also understand that expenditure on the dam this year will be only around $560,000. On a dollar for dollar basis this means that New South Wales will be drawing only $280,000 of the $1.5m which the Commonwealth has made available.

ANSWER.PARA: I also understand that the work which has been carried out has been on some designs and investigations and upon the improvement of an access road. It appears, therefore, that the New South Wales Government has given a low priority to the dam; it has done so in the past. I am advised that the New South Wales Government has, nevertheless, requested a long term commitment by the Commonwealth to meet a major contract for the construction of the dam. This request is being considered in the light of the next Budget. It is not true, as the article alleges, that a new funding proposal by the New South Wales Government has been rejected by the Commonwealth and that this could bring work on the dam to a stop. The situation is, as I have outlined, that almost $1.2 m is available to New South Wales, which it appears the New South Wales Government , for whatever reason, will not be utilising. Progress on the dam is in the hands of that Government. Commonwealth funds are available which the New South Wales Government is not utilising.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Under what circumstances will the Department of Social Security pay a special benefit to a young person under the age of 16 years who is living independently of his or her family? My question refers particularly to a circumstance where an under 16-year-old is trying to continue secondary schooling without family support and receives only the secondary allowance of $11 per week. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Special benefit is available to a person under the age of 16 years only in circumstances of hardship. Normally a child of that age is in the care and custody of his or her parents and is the responsibility of those parents, who continue to receive assistance by way of family allowance for the child. Unfortunately there are circumstances where children are not able to rely on that, although happily that is a minority situation in Australia. In circumstances where a child is left without support, it may involve the intervention of State community welfare departments, which have, of course, the primary responsibility for the protection of children who do not have the protection of their natural parents. In limited circumstances special benefit is granted by the Commonwealth to provide income support.

ANSWER.PARA: In general, social security benefits are not available as an educational benefit. As the Senate would know, educational benefits are provided in limited circumstances to secondary students through the secondary allowance scheme. Again, that is a benefit which is directed to the primary situation where children are at home. At a later stage of education, students can receive a Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, which is paid at a different rate according to whether the student is independent or living at home. I would have to check the practice of the past, but my understanding is that, in general , special benefit would not be seen as an appropriate form of support for a child at school.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TEACHERS FEDERATION: STRIKES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the disruption to schooling in the Australian Capital Territory presently being caused by rolling strikes being organised by the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation? Has the Federation claim been referred to arbitration? What is the present position of negotiations between the Public Service Board and the Teachers Federation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most people have heard reports about the rolling strikes which are being conducted by some teachers in the Australian Capital Territory. I think most people would have been cheered by the reports this morning that a large number of teachers appear to have ignored the request that they take strike action and have continued to remain on duty and available to the children whom they were employed to teach.

ANSWER.PARA: I have some information on the dispute from the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Public Service Board has a salary claim before it on behalf of teachers employed in the Commonwealth Teaching Service. The Commonwealth is, of course, generally a minor employer of teachers, the major employers being the large State education departments which employ the majority of teachers around Australia. The Board considers that it should follow standards established for teachers by the States rather than be a pace-setter in this area. I think, in light of the relative importance of the Commonwealth as an employer in this field, that is clearly an appropriate approach. The Board informed the Teachers Federation in February that Commonwealth teacher rates were at that stage broadly in line with State rates but that reviews of teacher rates were known to be in progress in the three eastern States. The Board undertook to respond to the claim as soon as the results of the reviews in those States were known.

The matter came before Justice Cohen in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 1 March 1982. Justice Cohen agreed that the Board did not have material on which to base an offer which would resolve the claim. After hearing arrangements she determined that teachers would have a guaranteed date of operation of new rates which resulted from the claim and set that date at 11 March 1982. Justice Cohen also asked that members of the Federation be realistic and indicated that stop work meetings would not achieve an earlier resolution of the problem. Notwithstanding those comments by Justice Cohen and the assured date of effect for any increases which might subsequently be awarded, the Federation has embarked on a program of rolling stoppages which are disrupting schools in the Australian Capital Territory and inflicting considerable hardship on parents and students. I repeat, however, that those teachers are fortunately inflicting less hardship than is apparently the Federation's objective and intention. The Board has reaffirmed that it will make an offer when the current reviews of State teacher rates are known. The Queensland decision was announced last Friday. The Victorian decision is understood to be imminent. In New South Wales the case is part heard.

I think most Australians and most honourable senators would find the actions of the teachers both unwarranted and unprofessional. They are inflicting hardship on innocent members of the Australian Capital Territory community in circumstances where their rights have, in fact, been fully protected by the arbitral authority by guaranteeing rises from a set date, as I previously mentioned. I join with others in urging the teachers to cease industrial action and to await the outcome of the New South Wales and Victorian reviews. The teachers have the alternative of proceeding with their case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 19 March when the claim is due to be resumed before Justice Cohen. I think it would be common ground that this sort of rolling strike action, or indeed any strike action which is likely to prejudice the education of children, is highly undesirable and should not be entered into by people with a professional responsibility.

Does the Government propose to equip Invincible with the Phalanx quick-firing gun system which can provide some defence against small numbers of missiles? If so, what will be the cost?

—Senator Mason seeks a great deal of information regarding the Government's proposed use of and equipment for HMS Invincible after it is purchased and is in Australia. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence to get a detailed answer.

—I have a supplementary question. From that answer can we assume that the Minister, who must have been present at at least some of the many Cabinet meetings which discussed this proposal, did not on those occasions comprehend the truly fundamental issues which the question poses?
—I thought Senator Mason would be pleased if I took the question on notice and gave him a serious and detailed answer. Otherwise, I might not provide him with the detail that he sought.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Health to an article which appeared recently in the Australian Financial Review and which was headed 'US Cancer Report Staggers Smokers' in which the United States Surgeon- General said that cigarette smoking was clearly identified as the chief preventable cause of death from cancer in our society and added that 30 per cent of all cancers-not just chest cancers-were attributable to smoking. His superior also urged non-smokers to avoid inhaling secondhand cigarette smoke even though the link there is still a matter of some scientific debate. Therefore, I ask: As the United States Surgeon-General is not likely to issue such a statement unless it is strongly backed by scientific evidence, will the Federal Government have the Department of Health examine that report as soon as possible and, if it is agreed with, give it great publicity, ban smoking in aircraft and in public buildings, particularly those which are airconditioned and in which much of the air is recirculated so that people are forced to breathe in smoke which they might not otherwise want, and recommend to the States that they enact such laws as necessary to protect non-smokers from having to put up with the most dangerous pastime that smoking obviously is?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will come as no surprise to honourable senators to know that I have some interest in the matter raised by Senator Townley. Senator Townley may or may not be aware that the United States Surgeon-General has issued not one report but some four or five reports and has said the same thing over 10 or 15 years. What he has said accords generally with what Senator Townley has set out-that the evidence seems to be that a whole range of cancers and other illnesses are associated with cigarette smoking. I think the evidence on that is fairly firm now and fairly widely accepted. Senator Townley asked about the effect of inhaling side stream smoke from other people. I think there is some evidence, but it is not as strong; the case is not as dramatic or the public health issue is not as immediate.

ANSWER.PARA: I assure Senator Townley that the reports produced by the Surgeon-General are always examined by the Government and that they are regarded as significant reports in the same way as the reports of the Royal College of Physicians are regarded as significant. Senator Townley would be aware that, following a report from a committee of this Senate, the Government announced a policy which set out as an objective a reduction in cigarette smoking in Australia. So, Government policy is clear. There is already a policy relating to government offices about which Senator Townley asked specifically. It has already been possible to work out in a co-operative way with Public Service unions and, in terms of Public Service policy, a set of arrangements which govern smoking in offices where Commonwealth employment occurs.

The arrangement in relation to aeroplanes is clearly quite unsatisfactory in terms of the number of non-smoking seats and the way in which the seats are arranged. I hope that the airlines continue to take a responsible view of this matter. As regards action in relation to the States, all we can do is make known to various State authorities Senator Townley's concerns on this very important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. How much did it cost the Government to print and circulate the Prime Minister's letter to the electors of Lowe? Is the Minister aware of any precedent for a Prime Minister panicking so much in a by-election that he authorises a flooding of an electorate with personal explanations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know the cost of the letter. I will ascertain it. As to precedent, there was no panic. There was a clear misunderstanding of Government policy. It is the duty of a government to clarify its policy to the people of Australia. I understand that the Australian Labor Party has had its difficulties. I simply say that I will find out how much money the letter cost.
—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Transport give consideration to the restructuring of international air fares to include Tasmania in the allowable international stopovers?

—The interest of Senator Watson in this matter as it affects Tasmania is well acknowledged. I have no immediate information on the point he raises. I will refer the question to the Minister and obtain a reply.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Defence advise whether 600 homes currently under construction in the Rockingham Shire in Western Australia are in fact being constructed for the Department of Defence to be used for United States military personnel on rest and recreation leave?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and concerns the allocation of war service home loans to service personnel. Can the Minister advise whether there are any plans to grant reserve personnel who have completed 15 years of part time service access to such war service home loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Service Homes Act was amended in 1973 to permit the granting of loans to regular servicemen and women who completed three years effective full time service after 7 December that year. The period of qualifying service was subsequently increased to six years with a commitment to further service for those who joined the regular Defence Force after 16 August 1977. That category of regular service men and women will become eligible for benefits after August 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: The need for restraint on public sector expenditure has obliged the Government to continue the waiting period for loans to buy a home which was instituted by the Labor Government as a period of 14 months in 1975. It was reduced by this Government in the 1980 Budget to 10 months. At present I can see little prospect of being able to reduce that period further so as to allow reserve personnel to be eligible for this kind of loan. Reserve personnel do receive some considerable benefit insofar as the income they earn from their service to the nation is tax free.

TALK.START.PARA: —When does the Minister for National Development and Energy anticipate he will be able to table the report of the Australian Water Resources Council working party? When will he be in a position to table the agreement recommending amendments to the River Murray Waters Act? Has he been advised by the South Australian Minister of Water Resources, Mr Arnold, that he intends to withdraw his objections to applications for further water diversion from the River Darling in New South Wales and his reasons for doing so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A working party of the Australian Water Resources Council has completed a report which has been submitted to the officers of the Commonwealth Government and the various State governments. The officers have perused it and submitted it to the ministerial council which is to meet, as I recall it, next month. The matter will be considered at the ministerial council which will come up with its own findings upon the paper and will make a decision on its publication. The paper cannot, as I have said in the Senate, become a public document until the ministerial council, whose property it is, agrees to its release.

ANSWER.PARA: The work on the legal document of the River Murray Commission is proceeding. I do not know precisely the timetable but good progress is being made. I repeat that, whether it is enacted in the short or long term, the agreement between the consenting parties is that they will function as though it were in full force. I will find out the date. I have not heard anything about the South Australian Minister, Mr Arnold, taking such action. If Senator McLaren wishes, I will seek to ascertain the information for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations a question. It bears on the fact that last year not one day passed without some form of industrial strife occurring on the Australian waterfront. In view of the national stoppage today of tug boats-I gather the stoppage will continue tomorrow-what steps are being taken to return some sense of order to the Australian ports where industrial action seriously affects the Australian economy generally and Tasmania particularly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer prefaced his question by a comment on the industrial strife last year in Australian ports. I think late last year my colleague, Mr Viner, released figures showing that there was a very serious state of industrial disputation during that year. In the latter part of 1981, in New South Wales in particular, there was a great deal of difficulty with numerous ships waiting outside ports, sometimes for weeks at a time. There was a bit of a flurry in this chamber when the decision was taken by the London based strike club to review its premium rates on Australian shipping strike insurance, which was seen to be an indication of a serious position for Australian importers, exporters and the community, which, ultimately, bears the cost of these strikes.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter came up at the Premiers Conference in Canberra on 19 February. There was agreement that urgent steps should be taken by the Commonwealth, the States, employers and unions to look at the waterfront and maritime industries. They were to examine things such as demarcation disputes to try to get some order and predictability into the waterfront. There was a meeting of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers on 4 March 1982 which, as required by the Premiers Conference, looked at these matters. Discussions are to be held as a matter of urgency with all parties in the maritime area. We received a further warning last week at the Australian-German trade symposium that we would need to improve our performance in this area.

Against that background, it is of course very disappointing to hear that Australian ports are again the subject of industrial disruption. As I understand it, the dispute is over a relatively small item. It concerns pay relativities between various classifications and the differences are relatively minor. The result at the moment is further delay, further cost, and that means a cost to everybody. It is the hope of the Government that this matter can be speedily resolved so that further damage is not dealt to our already tarnished international trading reputation. The matter is, as I understand it, currently receiving close consideration from the parties to the dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. It follows his reply to the question directed to him by Senator Scott concerning the construction of the Split Rock Dam. Will the Minister agree that the New South Wales Government has made more use than any other State of the funds that are available from the Federal Government on a dollar for dollar basis under the National Water Resources Program? If he is unable to say whether this is so, will he prepare a table and have it incorporated in Hansard showing the amounts of money that each State government has taken advantage of and used to date under the program? Finally, will he state the nature of the long term commitment that has been requested by the New South Wales Government from the Commonwealth to meet a major contract for the construction of the dam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the precise figures but I am very happy to get them. The fact of the matter is that under the National Water Resources Program it is assumed that, in the first place, the primary and dominant responsibility for water matters rests with the States and that this project is a supplementary one. A global amount is determined, in the budgetary sense, by the Commonwealth. It is then broken up into a notional amount for each State, depending on population and demography. The States are then invited to submit their priorities as to how they would like the programs introduced and financed on the basis that their priorities would be met on a dollar for dollar basis. My instinct is that the States generally over the years of this program, having accepted the dollar for dollar basis, backed it and, in fact, spent the money. It is only in more recent times that there has been a tendency not to take up the money.

ANSWER.PARA: I would be very happy to have a table prepared and incorporated in Hansard showing the amount offered, the amount accepted and the amount spent by each State. We should bear in mind that New South Wales, being a larger State, would tend to get a larger share than, say, Tasmania. However, I think it is true to say that Queensland has done very well in recent times. I will look at that matter. In previous years there have been determinations that there would be no commitment on other than a year by year basis. I rely on memory in saying that this matter arose at the tail end of the 1980 elections and there was pressure to get the dam started. The Commonwealth, which had no money for that program and which had not had any high priority request at all from New South Wales for the Split Rock Dam, authorised, I think through me-this is subject to checking- $500,000 towards a starting program. That was the start of the Split Rock Dam project back in 1980.

The next step was in relation to the money that was offered and accepted under the National Water Resources Program, as is normally the case on a year by year basis. As I understand it, the State has now asked for a significant amount of money-some $5m. Again, that is subject to checking. In itself, that is an unusually large sum in terms of the National Water Resources Program. That is bearing in mind we are talking about dividing some $34m among six States, so we are looking at around $5m for any one State. That would be unusual. The state of the matter at the moment is that an approach has been made and will be considered when we get the quantum, when we break this up, ask the States for their priorities and then determine how much money we can allocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a recent Press statement by Mr Frank Alcorta, president of the Northern Territory branch of the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia, in which it is claimed that a 56 page report compiled by Dr Keith Fleming, then Chief Director of Medical Services in the Department of Veterans' Affairs, on the use of chemicals in Vietnam, has been suppressed by the Government? I ask: Firstly, why was the report prepared and on whose authority was it prepared? Secondly, what was the nature of Dr Fleming's involvement in the preparation of the report? Thirdly, can the Minister assure the Senate that Dr Fleming has not been victimised by the Department because of his involvement in the preparation of this report? Fourthly, why has the report not been made public? In view of the widespread public interest in this report is the Minister in a position to table it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter to which Senator Jessop referred has been a matter of public knowledge for some time. I think it is approximately 12 months since Senator Grimes presented the second draft of this paper in this place. Since then it has been a public document. Certainly for almost 12 months there has been no motive on the part of this Government to suppress any document of that kind. In fact I would have thought that all interest in the matter would have fallen away since it became a public document.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent times, as has been referred to by Mr Alcorta in Darwin, there has been reference to a further document of which I was not aware but of which I became aware a few days ago. That document is merely a third draft of all those that have gone before and, I understand, substantially is no different from those which have been previously presented publicly. The second draft, to which I referred, was also made public by the Department of Veterans' Affairs by presentation to the Senate Committee on Science and the Environment some three months ago. Again, substantially there is no issue of concern there.

I deal now with the question why initially there was no presentation of that document. I correct Senator Jessop who said that that document was a report. Rather it was a collection of various items which have appeared in medical and other journals from time to time and was the property of one Mr John Evans, scientific adviser to the Vietnam Veterans' Association. It was never the property of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Dr Keith Fleming, who presently holds a very senior position in the Public Service of the Northern Territory and who moved there I think in May of last year, left of his own volition. Certainly there was no pressure or whatever might have been implied by Senator Jessop's question in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was getting a bit hot in the kitchen.
—He was promoted to that position.
—He was not promoted; it was the same level.

—Senator Robertson knows full well that it is a most senior position and a far more senior position than the one he held in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Although Keith Fleming assisted by putting together the various articles presented to the Department by Mr John Evans, he had no ownership of that collation of documents. Consequently, it is not his material. As I understand the position, its ownership does not vest in any way with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The only owner of this material that I can identify is Mr Evans himself. It remains for Mr Evans to make any public statement about the ownership of the material. I do not think he has done that over the 12 months period since it was first presented in this place, so I assume that he agrees with my conclusion. Senator Jessop asked me whether I am prepared to table the document. If that action will clear the air once and for all, I am quite prepared to do so. I table the report.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate concerned by the stringent special security legislation for this year's Commonwealth Games which has been enacted by the Queensland Parliament? Is he aware that the Premier of Queensland has threatened a state of emergency? Is the Australian Government concerned that the creation of this climate of fear is dissuading overseas visitors from coming to the Games and is damaging our national reputation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to know what are the special security regulations that the Queensland Government proposes to implement. It is a State Government matter. The State, through its police and security forces, has the complete responsibility for the individual security of people moving within the State. The Commonwealth has, through other agencies, responsibilities in terms of subversion and terrorism, but the matter of the security of an individual within a State is a State police matter. I will refer the matter to the Prime Minister to see whether I have omitted to deal with any special aspect of Senator Georges' question but as I see it any State running a State function must take charge of its security. Naturally enough, in the broader sense of security, the Commonwealth, I have no doubt, is playing its role.

—My question, which is addressed to the Attorney-General, relates to the negotiations towards an international convention on torture currently being conducted by a working group of the Commission of Human Rights in Geneva and, in particular, to the principle of universality of jurisdiction with respect to alleged tortures, which Australia recently accepted. I ask: Is it correct that all delegations of the Western group have now accepted the principle of universality of jurisdiction? If so, when will negotiations on the international convention on torture be completed and the convention implemented? Will the Attorney-General assure the Senate that the Australian Government will lend its full support to the implementation and enforcement of the convention to help ensure that it successfully promotes and protects human rights throughout the world?

—The discussions in relation to the proposed convention on torture are matters which fall primarily within the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I, of course, am concerned with the convention through the Ministerial Meeting on Human Rights. The general principles which Australia would be seeking to insert in that convention have been the subject of discussion at that human rights meeting. Of course, the States have a great interest in aspects of the convention, including a Federal clause. These matters have been discussed. The discussions have been led by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs. As I understand it discussions took place earlier this year in the Human Rights Commission which has been meeting presumably in Geneva. Representatives of State governments, as well as of the Department of Foreign Affairs, have been present. I understand that the discussions have not progressed and are not intended to progress towards a conclusion of the convention in the present session of the Commission. I will, however, refer the question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek a more detailed answer for Senator Missen. As I said, I do not think it is likely that that convention will be concluded at present.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Can he say whether the Government has yet found a buyer for the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops as recommended by the razor gang? Is it a fact that the books currently printed by the AGPS do not have a price printed on them as has previously been the case? Is the price now put on manually by the AGPS staff? Can the Minister say whether the new method of pricing the AGPS books allows commercial enterprises to sell the publications at a far higher price than would have been charged by the Australian Government bookshops?
—It would probably be best if I referred those quite detailed questions to the Minister for Administrative Services. I undertake to do that.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education concerns the Copyright Amendment Act 1980. I say by way of preface that it seems that there is no doubt that as a result of the new copyright amendments there is an increasing workload for teachers and extra costs for schools. When the legislation was in preparation was the Minister consulted and was any consideration given to providing extra funds to schools to offset these increased costs? Does the Minister agree that when extra costs are incurred by schools because they are complying with the law it is only equitable that the schools should be supplied with sufficient money to cover these costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer that question to my colleague the Minister for Education in another place and seek his comment.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources noted an item in the Daily Commercial News of 8 March stating that the Australian sheet steel industry is being swamped by a tidal wave of low cost imports? Can the Minister confirm whether that statement is correct? If it is correct, can the Minister advise the Senate of what action the Government has taken or intends to take to prevent dumping of steel on the Australian market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article of 8 March referred to and therefore I cannot comment upon its substance. I will refer the question to the Minister for Trade and Resources in the other place and ask him to study it and comment.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General and it is the one he has been long awaiting with trepidation on the subject of what he is doing about Dr Dintenfass. Has the Attorney-General read the transcript of the A .M. broadcast of 4 February which I sent him three or four weeks ago about the problems being experienced by Dr Dintenfass, the Sydney Hospital blood researcher, in getting Australian Government approval for the placement of a scientific experiment designed by him in a United States space shuttle flight? Does the Attorney agree that there is no serious possibility of the Australian Government ever being liable for significant damages arising out of this experiment, even in the wholly unlikely event of the spacecraft in question crashing into the middle of New York or Tokyo, and that other governments participating in the space shuttle program have mounted no similar objection? Does he further agree that the way this matter has been shuffled backwards and forwards for nearly four years between his own Department and the Department of Science and Technology reflects very unhappily on the quality of Australian Government administration? Finally, does he accept ministerial responsibility for what has happened so far as his own Department is concerned? What will he do to ensure an immediate favourable decision so that Australian participation in the program can proceed and that what is left of our international scientific reputation can be salvaged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans referred to me a record of an A.M. discussion in relation to this matter. My attention was thereby drawn to it. There is some element of a Blue Hills saga about this matter, but perhaps as Senator Evans has raised it more details should be referred to. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration provisionally accepted for inclusion in one of its proposed space shuttle flights an experiment by Dr Dintenfass of Sydney Hospital. The objective of the experiment is to observe the aggregation of human red blood cells in conditions approaching zero gravity. The acceptance by NASA of the experiment is , however, provisional upon the Commonwealth entering into an agreement with NASA in relation to the experiment. The proposed terms of an agreement were first forwarded by NASA to the Department of Science and Technology in March 1978. I do not propose to set out all the details of the proposal but I will make them available to honourable senators who are interested. The terms of the proposed agreement have been prepared from time to time, and the final agreement has still not yet been determined, although negotiations have been going on since March 1978.

ANSWER.PARA: The present problem is that NASA sought an undertaking from the Commonwealth in relation to sharing in meeting claims for damage caused to persons and property, being damage for which there is a liability in international law under the principles of the convention on international liability for damage caused by space objects. The terms of the undertaking were not limited to the consequences of Dr Dintenfass's actions. So it is not a question of whether the Commonwealth might be liable for what is clearly most improbable damage being caused by any of Dr Dintenfass's experiments; it is simply that we were asked to accept a share of liability in relation to damage that may be caused by the space shuttle carrying the experiment.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has every other country and they have all replied by return telex. You have taken four years.

—Does the honourable senator want Australia to assume liability, simply because it is carrying out one small experiment, for any damage that might be done generally? That is the problem. Legal advice has been given on several occasions in relation to this matter with a view to trying to resolve it . The most recent advice in relation to it was delivered to the Department of Science and Technology on 22 February. That is my latest information in relation to it. My Department is awaiting instructions before it can finally prepare the agreement. I understand that discussions are being held with the departments concerned in order to get this matter resolved as quickly as possible.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to the media report that the Northern Territory Government is requesting the Federal Government to fund a program to increase Aboriginal participation in central Australia's Uluru National Park. Has the Minister been able to approve a funding increase to allow additional training and management programs to go ahead with local Aboriginal participation?

—The short answer to Senator Kilgariff's question is that I cannot advise him whether funds are available. I can, in fact, advise him that requests have been received from the Chief Minister of the Government of the Northern Territory seeking additional Commonwealth funding of $100,000 per year to promote the kind of activities to which Senator Kilgariff referred; that is, increased Aboriginal involvement and participation in the operation and management of the Uluru National Park. The Commonwealth obviously is aware of the need for increased Aboriginal participation and training and would want to be involved in that kind of initiative. I think Senator Kilgariff would be aware of the success of some similar programs which have sought to involve Aboriginals in management at Kakadu National Park and which are being conducted by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. I understand that, as a result of action by the Central Land Council, both the Central Land Council and the Pitjantjatjara Council have indicated that they will be proposing a program for Aboriginal employment at Uluru. I can say to Senator Kilgariff that the outcome of such application is not yet known.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy and follows his attempted reconciliation of his statement and that of the Prime Minister on oil prices when, in answer to Senator Button yesterday, he paraphrased the Prime Minister, saying:

QUESTION.PARA: He quite clearly meant by that statement that, although for a time a surplus will be created in the world by a number of factors in which Australia has co- operated, in the longer term there will be a reversion to scarcity and higher prices.

I would like a direct answer to this question: If in the short or medium term there is a lowering of the price of Saudi light crude, will the import parity pricing policy be allowed to operate so as to reduce the price of petrol to Australian motorists? Why should not Australian motorists now take the benefit of those internationally pursued policies in which Australia has played its part and which appear to be leading to a sustained reduction in prices? Finally, approximately what percentage of crude oil imports over the last three months has been purchased for Australian distribution at prices below those set by the Saudi light crude bench-mark?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no need for me to make a reconciliation between the Prime Minister's statement and mine. I read out verbatim and did not paraphrase what the Prime Minister had said. In fact, the news item was completely the reverse of what the Prime Minister had said. That led to the comment that there was a difference between us. What the Prime Minister said and what I said are in parallel. The Prime Minister, as I understand it, has given an answer today in another place.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me remind Senator Tate that yesterday I repeated precisely what is the situation and what is the policy; that is, we have a policy of import parity pricing and that that pricing varies in the ordinary context each 1 July and 1 January. The Government looks at the movement of the Saudi Arabian light crude price and the exchange rate and makes the adjustment. It has done so over the years that import parity pricing has operated. Indeed, the Government has adjusted the price downwards twice due to exchange rate movements. That is the policy. I have said so before. I have not qualified that in any way at all.

The Government will await the meeting of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries on 19 March when it will be looking at both the reduction in the volume of oil throughout the world and any adjustment of price and the Government will look at the Saudi decision in that regard. We have been very fortunate in choosing Saudi light crude oil as a world bench mark. In fact, it has been much cheaper over the years than most other oils purchasable in the world. Therefore, we have had a very good benefit from that supply. There is no difference at all in what is being said by any Minister of the Government.

I am not aware of the precise purchases in recent months and the precise prices paid. That information can be secured, of course, and I will be happy to secure it. I want to make it very clear, though, that if the implication is that one should buy on spot markets instead of buying from countries on long term contract that will assure oil year in and year out, all I can say is that that course is absolutely perilous. The International Energy Agency in June last year drew the attention of all countries-it was unanimously agreed-to the fact that spot markets should not be operated upon. Australia needs to get some 33 per cent of its oil from overseas. It naturally wants to have secure markets. Australia has established very good relations with Saudi Arabia from which it gets a great bulk of its oil supplies. It would be to the nth degree perilous if one started playing around with spot markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never mentioned spot markets.

—I was asked whether we had bought oil from other countries such as Indonesia and Malaya. I will be very happy to get the information. The point I must stress is that in the interests of the Australian people we must be able to ensure that year in, year out we can obtain from reliable markets a particular quality of crude oil. We must be able to get it and not have precarious supplies. I will find the table providing the information. It may take some days to get it because it will have to be obtained commercially. I will be happy to let the honourable senator know. Perhaps the honourable senator would like it incorporated in Hansard as well.

—Is the Minister repre- senting the Minister for Industrial Relations aware that today's 9.30 a.m. edition of Dateline News Digest highlights four strikes presently occurring in New South Wales-one stopping shipping, one refusing care for psychiatric patients, another by petty session officers of the New South Wales courts and another by clerks at the Metropolitan Water, Sewerage and Drainage Board?
—There is one in Victoria.

—Only one strike, affecting Qantas Airways Ltd, is reported in Melbourne. Does the Minister intend to approach the Premier of New South Wales and ask him whether he would like to hand over his Government's industrial relations responsibilities which he so clearly cannot cope with to the Commonwealth?

—The lamentable state of industrial relations in New South Wales is well known. The interjections from the other side of the chamber are the best demonstration that the public of Australia could have about the Australian Labor Party's sensitivity in that area. The last 12 months have seen a series of very damaging strikes in that State. I will certainly refer the suggestion of the honourable senator to my colleague Mr Viner so that he can consider taking the matter up with the State Government of New South Wales.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the power station proposed to be built on Channel Island near Darwin. Is it a fact that Channel Island is in the tidal surge zone and could be flooded in the event of a cyclone? Will the Minister not agree that it would be inappropriate to build the station on Channel Island if it is within the tidal surge zone? I put this question to the Minister because of the amount of Federal funds involved in the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am heavily involved in the question of establishing the best possible power station in Darwin and have been heavily involved in the decision as to particular sites, this matter has not been put to me. Indeed, I should have had this in my mind because I am very well aware for other reasons of the dangers of tidal surge since I have had a responsibility for education and, in fact, there is a college within the primary surge area. The subject is one which in general terms I understand. No one has suggested that the site is within the primary surge area. I will take the matter on notice and find out about it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 27 October last, I asked a question without notice relating to some matters affecting the World Council of Churches and to some allegations it had made about the Western Australian Government. I asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume), in the event that he was able to provide me with information, to provide that information also to the Senate. That information has now been provided to me by way of a letter dated 8 March. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINISTER FOR ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Crichton-Browne,
On 27 October 1981 you asked a question without notice about matters contained in the World Council of Churches report 'Justice for Aboriginal Australians'.

Because the matters concerned the Western Australian Government's administration of Aboriginal affairs, I sought information from the Hon. W. R. Hassell, M.L.A., Minister for Community Welfare in Western Australia. Mr Hassell has now provided me with details in response to your questions.

You asked me to respond to the World Council of Churches report's claim that the Western Australian Government spent only $373,000 on Aboriginal health services in 1980 and that the staff providing those services are predominantly white. You also asked whether it is a fact that $6m was provided for community and health services alone in 1980, that it was predominantly directed towards Aborigines and that one-third of the staff are Aborigines.

Mr Hassell has informed me that in addition to funds provided by the Commonwealth, the State Government also makes significant contributions from its own funds. In 1979, the last year for which figures are available, the Western Australian Government spent more than $15.5 million on health care for Aborigines, in addition to funds provided by the Commonwealth. The need to train Aboriginal people in health care skills is clearly recognized, and in 1981 of a total of 261 nursing staff attached to the Community Health and Child Services branch of the Medical Department, 80 were Aboriginal health workers, 81 were Aboriginal camp nurses, and four were trained Aboriginal nurses.

You asked whether I was aware that the World Council of Churches report claimed that Western Australian funding for schools for Aborigines is very inadequate and that there is no consultation mechanism with Aborigines. You also asked whether it is a fact that there are 23 special and exclusive Aboriginal schools and an Aboriginal access program that fosters adult education, that last year the Western Australian Govern ment spent approximately $13m over and above the $ 25m which was provided by the Commonwealth, and that at the same time there is through the Aboriginal Affairs and Planning Authority a substantial mechanism for co-operation and consultation.

Mr Hassell has informed me that the Western Australian Education Department provides special programs for Aborigines in all age groups from pre-school to tertiary level. In 1980-81 it has been estimated that the State spent almost $14 .5m providing these programs.

You asked whether I was conscious of the fact that the World Council of Churches report claims that Aborigines in Western Australia have no land rights at all. You also asked whether it is a fact that the State's Aborigines have 21 million hectares of reserves, with tenure that is superior to freehold tenure.

Mr Hassell has replied that 19.2 million hectares of reserve land are vested in the Aboriginal Lands Trust and a further 2.5 million hectares are held by Aborigines under various forms of leasehold or freehold. It is also his belief that land reserved under the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority Act offers a form of tenure more secure than freehold as the consent of State Parliament is required if the status of the land is to be altered.

You asked whether I was aware that the World Council of Churches report claims that Western Australian police have no training with regard to Aboriginal matters and suggests the creation of a liaison committee. You also asked whether it is a fact that the Western Australian police force has an active force of Aboriginal police aides improving police-Aboriginal relations and that the Western Australian Government already has a special committee to further these relations.
Mr Hassell has responded that your comments with regard to arrangements for consultation and co-ordination and action taken to improve Aboriginal-police relations require no elaboration.

You asked whether 'inasmuch as the World Council of Churches report is a litany of untruths and distortions of fact' I would undertake to inform the Senate as to the precise position concerning that report in regard to these details.
I would have no objection should you wish to have this letter incorporated in Hansard.
Yours sincerely, PETER BAUME Senator N. A. Crichton-Browne,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA. A.C.T. 2600
