TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one more reference to something I mentioned on 25 February 1982, as reported at page 527 of Senate Hansard, which I believe will establish continuity between my two contributions to this debate. I referred to a statement that Senator Archer had made, and said :

SPEECH.PARA: He might like to be reminded that more small businesses, and fairly large businesses, have gone bankrupt since 1975 under the two governments with which Senator Archer has been associated than had gone bankrupt in the previous 20 years. It is largely as a result of the activities of this Government that so many bankruptcies are occurring not only in my State of Queensland but also in many other places.

The continuing attempt of the Government to impose these new sales taxes has created a wide division in the community. In my estimation, the Government has deliberately set out to divide the community further. In particular I refer to some of the activities of the Government in a number of areas. First of all the Government came in on a promise in 1975 to control inflation. It has been impossible for the Government to do so because it created the very areas in which inflation will increase. It also came in on a promise to reduce unemployment. Unemployment escalated and has now become a great social stigma on this country particularly with unemployed school leavers. Youngsters who left school four years ago still do not have a job.

The Government then turned itself to another field where it has used every possible opportunity to create a war. In particular I refer to the opposition of the Australian Labor Party to the establishment and export of the Sinai peacekeeping force. People will travel with that group and be involved in an organisation that does not come under the umbrella of the United Nations. It will create a small stir in the economy because of the purchase and manufacture of equipment and supplies and matters connected with travel but it will not be of any lasting benefit and could create a situation where this country will get involved in a much larger conflict as happened when we first sent people to Vietnam as advisers.

Almost every week since 1 January this year some senior member of the Government has come out and backed the United States of America in its attempt to blame Russia for a whole series of problems in Poland. This country ought to be helping resolve the problems of Poland and not causing further conflict by coming out behind America. Why we have to do this all the time I will never know . Mr Anthony, the Acting Prime Minister at the time went on record supporting the principle of the intervention in El Salvador. We are paying out money through the underground but that money would be much better spent in Australia so that the imposition of sales taxes would not be necessary at all.

The complaints about loss of revenue do not really stand up to public scrutiny. After all, the amount that will be lost in a full year is so small that it is virtually tea and bikkies money or petty cash in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). While on the one hand the Government is complaining about loss of revenue on the other there are no problems in spending money by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I witness the recent decision to have the Prime Minister's portrait hung in King's Hall at a cost of about $6,000. I witness also the sound proofing of the dining room at the Lodge at a cost of something like $2,500. I have never been privileged to sit in the dining room at the Lodge but I am told that it is a quite impressive place. The mere fact that sound proofing has to be carried out is rather ridiculous unless of course Malcolm has an argument with his wife or, alternatively, if the Governor-General says that the Prime Minister has not enough evidence for a double dissolution and his wife starts to throw her $8,000 set of dinner plates around. That was bought shortly after the Prime Minister said: 'Life was not meant to be easy'.

Yesterday the Prime Minister gave a speech of gloom about the economy. It appears, from the imports of today, that we seem to be taking in all of the financial problems of other countries. I realise that we cannot insulate ourselves against them but we do not have to co-operate and bring them in in large quantities, which is what this Government has done. There were complaints about the Australian Labor Party, when in office, obtaining money not through the usual laundered method but trying to obtain it directly. This Government has brought in more laundered Arab money by way of loans than the Labor Party ever proposed borrowing. The Government is still doing it, and it is doing it surreptitiously so that the public will not find out. The speech of the Prime Minister yesterday probably peeled another 3,000 votes off the Liberal Party candidate in Lowe. Heavens above, he is having enough of a battle now, what with the statement of Sir Phillip Lynch and other acts of this Government.

Today the Prime Minister tried to make some amends. He might get an extra 10 votes from the Greek residents of Lowe. I will quote shortly from his lunch time speech at the parliamentary luncheon in honour of President Karamanlis. One of the effects of yesterday's speech was to reduce the Australian dollar to its lowest point for 23 months-almost two years. In fact the American dollar at the moment is picking up. It was probably the most valueless paper around for some considerable time. We are being forced into this situation by the activities of the Government. The Prime Minister, when speaking at the luncheon for the Greek President, said:

. . . the Government has . . . decided that in addition to giving you personally something which recognises your attachment to the game of golf, we will, as a mark of recognition of your visit to Australia, introduce an ongoing program of awards to allow young Australians to study or obtain practical experience in Greece.
Each year, awards will be granted to approximately eight young people-
He is not sure how many-

with a wide range of skills and interest. For example, the awards will allow young Greek Australians to gain further knowledge of Greek culture and society, and thereby foster the maintenance and development of Greek cultural heritage within Australia's multicultural society.

Similarly awards may be given to migrant education teachers, ethnic community workers, student teachers, high school students or professionals working with Greek Australians, to allow them to study or work in Greece for a period of up to a year.
The Prime Minister concluded:

We will be announcing details of the scheme shortly and I believe it will not only strengthen the links between Greece and Australia but also add a further strand to the advancement of multiculturalism in Australia.

I hope that the Prime Minister's colleagues keep close scrutiny on his activities. He has no idea how the program will operate. There are no firm plans . The program will not be working by Christmas of this year. Unless there are continual reminders it will not happen. The awards situation is a bit like what happened when the Prime Minister was flying from the south to Darwin in 1975 as part of the infamous election campaign of that year. I am told on reliable authority that the Prime Minister said to one of his aides on the aeroplane: ' What will we give the so and sos in the Northern Territory?'. One of his aides said: 'Make them a new State'. He said: 'Good; that's it'. One of the Prime Minister's first announcements in Darwin-apart from what he said at a meeting he attended where he was not very well received-was to give the people of the Northern Territory a new territory with State-like powers. Apparently it gave him such a shock that he disappeared and went to his bed for two days while his wife carried on the campaign. Some people in the Northern Territory are still shocked by the results of what happened, particularly because they found out that they had to do most of the paying for the new State.

A report came into the chamber yesterday on the sale of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. The recommendation was made on the casting vote of the Chairman. It was apparently a deliberate attempt to reduce the Liberal Party vote in the Victorian election. Honourable senators will be aware from the debate that took place in the chamber and the debates which will follow that the representative of my party and the representative of the Australian Democrats put in minority reports. There were two Western Australian members of the Liberal Party who, with the aid of the casting vote of one, the Chairman, were able to put the Ordnance Factory up for sale. The fact that a lot of workers will be displaced does not really matter I suppose! I was interested to hear the federal member who represents that area whistling like a small boy in the dark on a radio program still backing the Government. He is a very brave man. His seat will go too.

I had cause recently to look at the internal workings of a government department. The matter I refer to is connected with the infamous activities of the razor gang. The amalgamation of colleges of advanced education and universities has cost this country probably hundreds of thousands of dollars in the short term and undoubtedly it will cost more in the long term. Because the razor gang said the amalgamations had to be done they went ahead. It did not matter what the academics, the students or the councils thought; the amalgamations went ahead. The government department to which I refer-I will be giving it a very good airing in this chamber before the session finishes-is another area where the razor gang nominees were able to say to the departmental head that one section of the department would go. They had not looked at the establishment. They had not looked at the ramifications of the decision. They had not looked at the very skilled way in which that section was being run. They made the decision before they looked at anything. That decision is being implemented at a cost to the taxpayers of this country of many thousands of dollars. The section of the department is in the process of being abolished.

I received a phone call the other day to say that we would lose the television studios at Townsville and Rockhampton. I could not believe it. The Liberal Party complained about the centralism of the Australian Labor Party Government while it was in office. The centralism now being practised under the guise of so- called federalism is much worse than anything we ever dreamed of.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 419 and ask you to rule whether the subject matter of Senator Keeffe's speech is relevant to the issue before the Chair.

—I have listened to Senator Keeffe. The debate has been very wide ranging. Those who have occupied the Chair during this debate have been tolerant of many speakers. I think that Senator Keeffe should have the same liberties as others have had.

—Mr Deputy President, I will reply to the point of order in spite of the fact that you have ruled that way. I am endeavouring to build up my case by showing that this Government is careless with money in many areas and acts like a skinflint in other areas. Members of the Government are acting like skinflints and sitting down and crying because they will not pick up a few million dollars in sales tax from that section of the community which can least afford it. Part of this action is caused by the corruption of the Government to which I have referred in this chamber before. After the announcement of the sales tax in the Budget many people in the retail section selling school books, clothes and other things that come under the ambit of the nine amending Bills immediately applied the sales tax. Some of them are still charging it. If the Government were as demanding in the avoidance of corruption within its own ranks and the knocking off of people's money as it is opposed to other things, particularly trade unions, it would have people from the Taxation Office policing this area to see that the sales tax is not charged. On 16 February when the Parliament reconvened some people in the community thought that the Bills would be passed that day. A shop in my region immediately put up a notice in its front window-it is a big business-saying that all stationery, et cetera, would go up as from that day. The shop added the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on the understanding that the Government would pass the Bills that day. As far as I know, it is still charging the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax and it will make a big rake-off. Let us see whether the Government cares. That is another part of the corruption.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw another clear indication of corruption yesterday with regard to the laundering of money by the New South Wales Liberal Party. I understood that the Government and members of the Liberal Party were opposed to corruption. They will get their donations but, to avoid the provisions of the electoral funding Act which the people of New South Wales have approved, they will transport their money to Queensland and then bring it back as laundered money. There will be some very substantial donations in the $5m that the New South Wales Liberal Party plans to raise. Some of those donations will come from the illegal sale of marihuana and hard drugs. That has been happening in the past. To send the money interstate and bring it back is a way of laundering it which will enable the Liberal Party with its so-called opposition to drugs to keep its eyes closed for a long time. It will never get caught up. The Government is less than honest in trying to force this series of nine amending Bills on to the Australian people and hit at the people at the bottom of the income scale. It does not deserve to have the Bills carried. I hope that every honourable senator on this side of the chamber and a few defectors from the other side will, in the final vote, make sure that the Government does not get any of these amending Bills through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make what is probably an unusual contribution to this debate on sales tax. Firstly, I wish to criticise the Government. I then wish to criticise the Opposition and the Australian Democrats . I am not suggesting that I am the only person who is right, but I think legitimate criticisms can be made and are appropriate in relation to the whole of the debate. The Government has, I believe, failed to do adequately what it set out to do. The justification of the Government for the sales tax legislation was to effect a real redistribution between direct and indirect taxation in Australia. The imposition of a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax will not do that. In my belief it should not be done little by little. The Government should grasp the nettle and say: 'We will effectively redistribute the balance. To do that, we will propose the introduction of a sales tax or some other form of taxation of an amount which will enable a withdrawal of a specific amount of personal taxation'. I regard it as unfortunate that that has not happened. I believe the Opposition has failed to adhere to its supposed principles in relation to the Senate. I will develop that point a little further in due course. I think the Democrats have demonstrated that 'keeping the bastards honest' is not only a hollow statement but also politically flexible for personal advantage.
—It is certainly not easy.

—It is certainly not easy. I accept Senator Mason's contribution. I have some sympathy with a number of the problems he has experienced. Unfortunately, we have seen a demonstration that such a principle is not easy to put into practice. Eventually-the Government has the same problem -political flexibility and personal advantage can outweigh the best of principles. I believe that today is a sad day in the life of the Parliament. I do not find any joy in making the comments I will now proceed to make.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point concerns the distinction between equity and efficiency in the taxation system and political expediency. Some years ago I was involved in campaigning for the establishment of a taxation inquiry which eventually led to what became known as the Asprey Committee. This Committee investigated taxation. Unfortunately, one of the things that I repeatedly talked about happened. The Committee approached the matter with a form of tunnel vision. It was circumscribed by its own expertise. It looked at the existing system and played with variations of it instead of looking at the basic principles of a taxation system-equity and efficiency. That is that this debate today and over the past few weeks ought to have been all about. It ought to have been about equity and efficiency. It ought to have been about the cost of the collection of taxation and the fairness or otherwise of the distribution of the load of taxation.

I was impelled to refer to evidence that was given by Professor Johns and Mr Sheehan to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in May 1973. I think the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) might well recall the evidence that was given, she being a member of the Committee at the time if I am not mistaken. On 1 May 1972 and 14 May 1973 those academics were endeavouring to make the point to the Committee looking at the matter of probate and the second and relatively minor aspect was social redistribution but that first aspect should be economic efficiency. Economic efficiency is far more important.

When we look at the matter of sales tax, I believe that it is ludicrous for us to consider sales tax at 2 1/2 per cent. A 2 1/2 per cent sales tax is equivalent to three months inflation, on the lowest possible base of inflation that we can anticipate for this year. We hear plaintive cries about how dreadful it is that the children of the less well off in the community will have to go bare foot to school. Will this happen for the sake of 50c? A sales tax of 2 1/2 per cent on a pair of school shoes amounts to 50c or less.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are at the wholesale level, not the retail level, of course. Do you know that?
—It is about 50c.
—Well--
—If it is not, perhaps Senator Mason can correct me and point out that it is an extra 75c. It is of that order. I do not think that is what we are talking about.
—It is less than 50c.

—I am delighted by the contributions from both sides. I do not mind because I think the point is valid. It does not matter whether the amount is more or less, so long as the amount is only a little either way. The point is we are talking about the equivalent of three months inflation. Talking of three months inflation brings us to what is the real matter of concern to the people of Australia. Are we going to control inflation in this country? Are we going to get a fair distribution of the wealth of this country? Are we going to have an equitable and efficient tax system for whatever the needs of the country without carrying on with the nonsense and political vote getting which are so easy by pretending concern for somebody and by saying, 'We'll save you from the 50c a year extra for your kids' school shoes'? That is why I find it more than lamentable that we have had a debate on what is not the subject of debate . We have had a debate about platitudes. We have had a debate about a government's desire not to interfere, to do effectively what it ought to be doing. We have had a debate about how we can readjust principles to ensure some justification for doing what we promised we would never do. That is why I regard this debate as one of hollowness and shallowness and this day as very regrettable and sad.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Labor Party Opposition and the Democrats have totally failed the test by putting their own expedient interests ahead of the national interest. The situation is that if we could control inflation more effectively than we have we would far exceed anything that might happen as a result of this minor tax measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the sales tax built into the CPI to account for inflation?

—Senator Tate will no doubt remember that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) explained why we had had a relatively high figure for the consumer price index published for the last three month period- they were deliberate measures by the Government on a once only basis. Of course, we then have the flow-through effects of the increased sales tax. I would have thought that the same explanation could reasonably be given now. If the first was justifiable, so too is the second justifiable so long as everybody is told in advance what is to be done. What we have got is a situation in which a little has been done and there is a fear-broad spread in the community-that it will increase further. There is a fear that a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax really is not what it is all about but that the tax will increase to 5 per cent, 7 1/2 per cent or 10 per cent. That is my criticism first of all of the Government. I think it ought to have decided on a fair redistribution between the direct and indirect taxation levels and then applied that. In other words, the Government should have introduced the whole measure for what was required by way of sales tax if we could not have a value- added tax or any other from of taxation that was suggested and discussed over a period.

SPEECH.PARA: Having decided what was necessary to redress the imbalance, which I think most people in the country agree exists, we should then have directly reduced, by the same amount, the percentages of income tax. Had we done that I do not believe there could have been an objection from any responsible party in this country. I do not think there could have been an objection from any responsible citizen in this country. It is my regret that this is not what has happened.

Having said that, I will move to some other matters in relation to sales tax. As I said earlier, I do not find this an enjoyable debate. I believe the sales tax should have been either significantly higher or not introduced at all. The real misfortune has been undebated. I refer to the rationalisation of many sales taxes which have been increased not by 2 1/2 per cent but by anything up to 25 per cent. I believe there has been no recognition in this debate of the extent to which the so-called rationalisation has, in fact, meant a huge restructuring of the tax system. What has been attacked by the Democrats and the Labor Party is not the real point at all. As I said earlier 2 1/2 per cent sales tax is equivalent to three months inflation. I really cannot believe that honourable senators are doing other than posturing in saying that they want to go to the barricades about a tax increase the equivalent of three months inflation.

Some of the nonsense talked has been in relation to public expenditure which would increase the cost to revenue by far more than 2 1/2 per cent. Repeatedly we have had suggestions by the Democrats and the Labor Party Opposition as to how we ought to spend the taxpayers' money far more fluidly and fluently than we do at the moment. In the name of concern for individuals in the community we have had the suggestion that almost every aspect of welfare expenditure should be higher. But an attack is then made by the Labor Party and the Democrats upon any of the measures whereby such increases could come about. I do not want to get into the debate about the Invincible. I do not want to get into the debate about some other aspects of Government expenditure because particular elements of those measures can always be debated in considerable detail. One fundamental fact-I hope that Senator Mason who will follow me in the debate will deal with it-is that we cannot spend money unless we get money. Any government has to raise the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Government budgeted for a domestic surplus.

—The Government did not budget for a domestic surplus but it budgeted for a much smaller deficit than we are going to have thanks to Ronald Reagan and Reaganomics. Perhaps I misunderstood the interjection but the fact is that the management of the Australian financial system has been thrown out of gear by two things. The first is the impact of the largest economy in the world- that is, the United States economy-and the way it is being managed and the second is the unjustified, unwarranted and unprincipled intervention of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, contrary totally to everything that they said that they would adhere to as to whether a government could govern this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the really important questions that we have to face are the balance of power between the two Houses-the balance of power in respect of whichever party happens to be the elected government of the day-and the responsibility of an upper House to be a House of review and not a government in exile. I well recall writing a review for the Australian newspaper at a time when I was an occasional writer for that newspaper on a book on Don Chipp and the Australian Democrats. I said at that time that the problem that the Australian Democrats, Don Chipp and whoever else came in would face was whether they would be members of a House of review or whether they would attempt to be a government in exile. I still believe that everything that they have done since they have been here has demonstrated the validity of the point that I was making -a minor party in an upper House cannot be a government in exile. What they are trying to do in relation to this legislation, for the sake probably of their own personal popularity in the electorate, is to be a government in exile.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not getting much support for your view amongst the pundits.
—Amongst whom?
—The pundits; the others who think they know all about it.
—It may well be that, as so often happens, I am in a club of one. I am entitled to put my views.
—Sure. I am not criticising your chance of putting a view. Support is handy.

—Yes, but quite often it is also unlikely when one does not put a simplistic view and one tries to look a little beyond it. I thank Senator Robertson for his interjection. To continue, I find it somewhat regrettable that there are such dramatic examples of a total aboutface by members of a political party whose pressage, so far as their arrival on the scene as a force in the land is concerned, was that they were going to 'keep the bastards honest'. What they have done is fail to keep themselves honest. That I think is regrettable, not as a political point-scoring exercise, but as an aspect of government, of the parliament and of the political development of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a great deal of sympathy for the idea that Executives ought to be kept honest. I have already indicated that I have a great deal of criticism about some of the things that Executives do not do. But I wonder how we can learn, how we can feel that we have advanced democracy in Australia, and how we can feel that we have advanced the balance between a House of review and an arrogant Executive which is what most executives are by nature. I am not saying this in any way offensively to any honourable senator but the natural propensity of an Executive is to be arrogant and the natural function of a House of review in a checks and balances system is that it should endeavour to offset that arrogance. The net result has been that we find expediency and convenience lead to a situation where people, having had pressure applied to them, say: 'We made a mistake. We will review it because we want to make sure that we come back next time'.

I regret that we have not adequately-I hope Senator Mason will do so adequately -addressed ourselves to the real question. The real question is: Who will pick up the tab? If we disallow any area of a government's taxation, I think, as part of our disallowance of it, we have to say by what means of efficiency, and by what means of increasing other areas of revenue or decreasing areas of expenditure we will offset what we have as a House of review intervened in, interfered with and redressed.

I had considerable personal problems in 1974 and 1975 in relation to what the Opposition of the day did in the Senate. But I thought eventually that there was justification for what was done in 1975. I simply refer to my speech in this chamber on 22 October 1975 and the contretemps which was then taking place. Having referred to my speech I will not quote from it. It is there expressing my views if anybody wishes to see whether I am now taking a different view from the one I took then.

I wonder what the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party, who are hell bent on chucking out a small government taxation measure, will do about tax avoidance . Have we not a problem where a large percentage of the community is being kept one way and another by a relatively small percentage of the community? Have we not a major problem of obtaining efficiency in taxation collection? I suggest that one of the most efficient ways is by a sales tax. If the sales tax is small enough how do honourable senators find such incredible objection to it except that it is a means of gaining popular support to say: 'We do not want to see something which is infinitesimal in relation to real costs and the subsequent explosion of those costs being passed on'.

The cynical attitude which has been adopted by those who are opposing this measure is unfortunate. They will not spend their time to develop some real thoughts about the things that are really concerning us. Let me use as an example of the sort of concern that I have the superannuation problem of Trans Australia Airlines. Trans Australia Airlines has run up a bill of $180m in eight years. That company has capital and reserves of $31m and, in the whole of its 36 years of operation, it has never made a profit which amounts to $180m; it has never made a profit and paid tax which amounts to $180m; but it has a liability at the moment which the taxpayer will have to pick up of $180m. Is not that a matter of real concern when one projects that sort of loss cost or unfunded liability because of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme applying to the largest percentage of TAA's employees? Would not the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party be more honest to the future of Australia if they were to address themselves to the problem of what will happen if we continue to have an unfunded superannuation scheme which, at the moment, is probably unfunded to the degree of something in excess of $2 billion and is going up by dramatic amounts? For example, TAA's scheme went up by $40m last year. Would not we be better as a country and as a House of review if we paid a little more attention to letting the government of the day get on with the measures that it believes are necessary to enable it to raise the revenue for the expenditures which governments are always being called upon to provide-whichever government it might be-rather than trying for some petty purpose to disallow some pinpricking area of it without responsibility, without saying: 'What are we to do to cover it? What are we to do to ensure that there is adequate provision to provide for pensions, other aspects of welfare, government services generally, defence and all the other things?'

I find it disappointing that we appear to be reaching a stage in Australia where the cartoon in the Australian on Monday of this week was so true. The cartoon was a picture of a number of aged members of the community at a maternity hospital saying: 'How soon can the new born babe enter the workforce so that he can contribute towards our keep?'. I would have thought the problem of the aging, the problem of providing a balance between those in the community who are working and those who are not, the problem of providing for the real needs of the weaker-I do not mean that in a patronising sense-members of our society, the problem of ensuring that there is not a disincentive and the problem of ensuring that people pay their taxation contributions fairly are matters which ought to be the subject of debate in this chamber, rather than the question of how the Democrats can justify changing their view.

I will not quote again what Senator Mason said last year. I think he has heard it said enough times. But he was fairly positive last year and his party has found itself in the position of having to change its view. I simply ask: Can the Senator Evanses and the Senator Masons of this world come back to something which is a little closer to the real problems of Australia than the pettiness of debating something which amounts to once-only three months inflation and stop pretending that it will make a real difference to the way in which the country operates? I shall refer very briefly to what some people have said. Senator Evans, the shadow Attorney-General, in August last year said:

. . . I, in conjunction with many others, have since the events of 1974 and 1975 used fairly interchangeably the expression 'blocking of Supply', 'blocking of money Bills' and 'blocking of Budgets'. I acknowledge that. There are ample quotes that can be produced of my saying that, as a matter of principle, it is inappropriate for the Senate not only to block Supply but also to block money Bills or Budgets.

One of the incredible things that has happened in this country is that since 1975 all the Democrats have sworn allegiance to the principle that they will not block Supply, but they have not defined it. The Labor Party has complained bitterly about what blocking of Supply meant to the government of the day in 1975 but prior to that there had been in excess of 5,000 individual votes by Labor Party senators to block Supply in its broadest sense. I wish to conclude this debate by saying that I think the quotation from Senator Evans that I have just given and the much quoted quotations from Senator Mason all amount to a degree of unfortunate humbug which has misdirected the real debate which ought to have taken place. We should have been debating where we are going in this country; the real problems of an ageing society; the problems of an imbalance in the taxation system a system which does not provide equity to the taxpayers, which does not provide adequately for the needy in the community, which permits massive tax avoidance as a practice to take place in the community and which could be regarded by any person only as being distorted and in need of review. Rather than having that review take place we have had a shallow, superficial vote-catching debate about what amounts to three months inflation. I regret that the Government, if it wanted to redress the imbalance between direct and indirect taxation, did not actively go ahead to introduce sufficient sales tax to enable that redress to take place. I think it is regrettable that it did not pass it on directly to the taxpayer by way of reduction in personal income tax, but I regard as far more regrettable the vote-buying public stances which have been taken by others, avoiding the real questions and show-ponying the situation .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae shed a good volume of crocodile tears in his speech. I am sure that he will forgive me if I say that my heart is not truly rent by them. It is as if he were saying that changes of mind have never happened or are inconceivable in his own party. Of course, changes of mind may well be necessary as circumstances change in a fast changing world and, indeed, if all parties to an agreement-which politics is or should be -do not carry out what they said they would do. That, of course, was exactly the case with the change in the Australian Democrats' policy on these iniquitous, unjust and dangerous Bills which proposed to impose taxes on the basic necessities of life for everybody-clothing, footwear and shelter. Since I will be the last Democrat speaker in this debate I make it plain at this stage that the Democrats' policy approves of sales tax on luxuries and goods of that type. When the Bills were brought forward for the greater mass of sales tax we voted for them. Indeed, we resisted the blandishments of the members of the Australian Labor Party, who wanted us to vote against the total sales tax package. Let it be quite clear that our argument concerns the sales tax on necessities.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish at this stage to deal with the statutory declarations which were signed by the Democrat senators during their campaign before the last Federal election and which have been mentioned from time to time during this debate. In no way would a Democrat vote against the sales tax on necessities offend or go against those statutory declarations. The statutory declarations pledge the Democrat senators not to vote against Supply. Point number one is that we are not debating a Supply Bill. The declarations also pledge the Democrat senators not to vote against taxing measures in such a way as would make it impossible for the Government to govern. These taxes on necessities represent well under one per cent-I repeat, well under one per cent-of total Budget revenue. I suggest that anyone who says that our voting against the Bills would make it impossible for the Government to govern is either a fool or a rogue or both. Let us lay that assertion to rest for ever.

I indict the Government for the repetitive way in which it has carried out this debate. There has been a considerable attempt at political point scoring rather than getting the business of the Senate completed. On my rough figures it costs some $14,000 an hour of taxpayers' money to run the Senate. I think that should be an argument of great weight in favour of our getting on with our business expeditiously. So far in this session we have completed virtually nothing at the cost I have just mentioned. Looking back over the lengthy debate that has taken place so far, I think Government members have been making very heavy weather of it, trying to show that black is white and that wrong is right. We have had in the debate such gems as Senator Messner trying to say that sales taxes on necessities are not sales taxes on necessities, and getting into trouble for appearing to say that children should not wear shoes to school. Indeed, Senator Messner has implied quite clearly that it is not necessary to wear clothes. Clothing, I would have thought, is definitely a necessity. I think there has been a great degree of double talk and double think in this debate, which is to be greatly deplored.

Senator Lewis attempted a similar line with even more disastrous consequences, which I will not recall to mind at this stage. Senator Missen made unctuous noises about how bad it was in principle for the Senate to vote against money Bills, conveniently forgetting his own vote in 1975, recorded in Hansard, against Appropriation Bill (No. 1)-the major supply Bill. Senator Watson seemed to see the whole issue as an anti-Fraser one which is, of course, complete nonsense. I prophesy that most Government senators and members are very pleased indeed that these sales taxes will not go ahead. I can imagine them when they are back in their electorates talking with constituents or with the Party faithful who may say: 'Now look, what is going on? Why are you pushing these sales taxes on necessities? The taxes are new, they are unfair, they produce peanuts in terms of money, they are costly to collect and we are getting massive electoral flak over them'. As all members of this place and the other place know full well, those things are all true. I presume that the Government member or senator would then cast an uneasy eye over his or her shoulder, move in closer and say: 'Well, privately, I know that you are right about that, but we had to go along with it'.

We are all here as members of Parliament and are pledged to do the best we can for the people who put us here. As Senator Chipp has said, we made an error in judgment in assuming that Government members would do the decent thing-would listen to the massive pressure from their electorates and would insist that the Government give income tax cuts. Senator Peter Rae mentioned that matter only a few minutes ago. We like to give people the benefit of the doubt. We like to feel that this will be a reasonable place in which to work and in which things will get done, but we are learning very fast. We know that members of the Government are prepared, presumably, to vote against their consciences and what they know the public wants. That is demonstrably the case here and that, I suggest, has changed the ground rules a great deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody wants to pay tax, do they?

—I will deal with that matter in a moment. In this debate we have heard a remarkable amount of breast beating and tub-thumping from the Government about how wicked the Australian Democrats are even to contemplate denying the Government the right to rip off not only the poor but also the greatest proportion of Australian families with this ingenious new flat tax, which of course it is, on the necessities of life. While we are back on this subject of changing minds or breaking undertakings I will stress again: What about the assurances from the Government last year that the new sales taxes were intended to broaden the tax base and that they would be compensated for by income tax cuts? I can see that now only as rather like the assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) during the 1980 Federal election campaign in Launceston that all future amounts derived from the crude oil levy would be passed back to the Australian people in the form of tax cuts or increased family allowances. We applauded that proposal when we heard it in the first place because we thought it was a marvellous and fair idea and because we thought in the past that to do otherwise was wrong. Here again the Government regarded the crude oil levy merely as a flat tax on everybody and did not use it for proper purposes such as reasonable research into energy replacement.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Harradine, other Democrat senators and I have raised that matter several times over the last year or so, so there is no shortage of examples of the Government changing its mind and breaking its promises. I mention those two examples because they have a very direct link with these sales tax Bills. They have of course been an influence, and a significant influence, on the Democrats' decision to oppose the Bills. They certainly profoundly influenced my personal decision. Of course the key point is that the Bills need not be opposed at all; they could be passed here in the Senate today. All the Government has to do is to remove from the Bills the proposed taxes on building materials for new houses, on shoes and clothing and on the means of information and books, and we will pass the Bills with great pleasure.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a flash.

—In a flash; there would be no argument and no debate. We have always made that clear, but the Government is so pig-headed that while screaming out that it cannot do without the $300m a year revenue from these Bills it will not bend its pride to gain itself close to $100m a year-I think it is $95m a year-which would accrue if the Bills were passed without the necessities of life included in them. So we conclude that the argument is not really a sincere one at all and that the Government is not really interested in the revenue from the Bills. Certainly, Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers' Association does not think that the money involved is very important. 'Mere petty cash' he called the proceeds of these Bills. So they are, amounting to well under one per cent of the total Budget revenue. I take Senator Peter Rae's point: Would the Democrats justify how the money could be saved? I will do that immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not need the money. If it really feels it does need the money it could consider not going ahead with the purchase of the proposed naval white elephant, the aircraft carrier Invincible, whose value to us and whose ability in warfare is quite unproven at this stage and for which the Government has not brought forward any argument at all, but these taxes on necessities would have to run for five years to pay for that ship when she has aircraft in her, and fairly inadequate aircraft too. So let us have an end to all this specious nonsense about these new sales tax Bills and saying that the Government will go broke over them. Of course it will not.

Let us now look at the Bills themselves and their consequences, which ought to be the sheer nub of this debate. The Bills propose to introduce a new and sinister element into the financial affairs of every Australian. If the Democrats did not believe that we would not be taking the action we are taking. We have thought most carefully about this matter and we dislike intensely, just as the community dislikes intensely, the new principle which the Government dreamed up from somewhere, which is simply to levy a flat tax on people for things they must have, regardless of their ability to pay. I repeat that because it is worth repeating: The new principle being introduced by the Government is simply to levy a flat tax on people-by a 'flat tax' I mean the same amount for everybody-for things they must have, regardless of their ability to pay. That includes the very poor or the people without jobs.

Senator Peter Rae would not know what it is like for a family on the dole to have to stay alive. He thinks that 75c on a pair of shoes is nothing. I can take him to families to whom that is an almost insuperable obstacle if they have three children, in which case it will cost another $2 or $3 to get their children to school. They do not have that money. They are thinking in margins of cents now. Senator Peter Rae, like all of us here, does not have to think that way; we are rich in comparison, but those people do have those kinds of problems . I can assure him that if he goes around some of the schools in western Sydney he will find plenty of children going to school in thongs, and that is getting quite common.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a different problem.

—I suggest it is not a different problem. It is very much the nub and the basis of it because the tax is initially quite small, and seems quite small. I interjected because I thought Senator Peter Rae was being a little less honest and a little more forgetful than he usually is when he said it was only 2 1/2 per cent. It is 2 1/2 per cent on the wholesale price. The book people have said already that because of the enormous costs of collecting this tax it could be up to 10 per cent on some things. So it is a very different matter if it should be 10 per cent. The Democrats are worried enough about that. We might have thought it would be okay but, as eminent authorities in this country have stated, there is a real problem about this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Peter Rae said, 2 1/2 per cent is hardly worth collecting. We found that a most sinister development, and of course it is a most sinister development. I think the Australian Taxpayers' Association said that this 2 1/2 per cent will barely, if at all, cover the costs of collecting the tax. What is the most logical deduction one can make from that? It is that the Government proposes to increase it year after year. Why would it have introduced it otherwise? This is the thin end of the wedge: The proposal is to tighten the screws year by year to provide extra money for the Government's pet projects, such as the elitist Casey military university here, the new and permanent Parliament House and other costly projects of little intrinsic value to the people. I think that is the key point. That is what really worried the Australian Democrats: Our conviction-we think it is a reasonable conviction-that this was not just one small tax but a new principle in Australian taxing, and an unfair one, which indeed the Government intended to raise over the years. Indeed , if that were the case it would mean that the new taxes would represent an arrogant and, I think, most impudent attempt to take even more money from those on low or little incomes and redistribute that money to the very rich. As Senator Rae said, people already defraud the tax system by a variety of legal, ingenious and immoral schemes. None of us want to see that happen.

I am a little concerned that the Government wrings its hands over these tax avoidance schemes, but in many cases at least it appears-I say 'appears'-that the door is shut only after the horse has bolted. That is something I think we have to look at carefully. Having benefited these rich people, or the rich people having benefited themselves, through tax loopholes to the tune of millions on millions of dollars, there is of course a need for money to replace it. The Government decided to compensate for that loss by imposing this new flat tax on the poor and battling families of this country. I say, on the logic I have presented, that the Government intended not only to introduce it but also to see that it went up year by year. We felt that we had to grasp the nettle. There is no way that we could say we would let it go this year and then allow the Government to raise it again next year. The nettle will have to be grasped now.

The Australian Democrats, through exercising our delaying powers, made it possible for the Australian people and major interest groups to react to these new Bills, and they have done so in no uncertain fashion. A recent Gallup poll which was taken in all Federal electorates showed 89 per cent of Australians opposed these new Bills and only 7 per cent approved of them. This result has been confirmed by a tremendous surge of community interest which has come to the Democrats in particular since we have been, we might say, in the eye of the storm here. The Government has been told in no uncertain manner that people understand well enough the unusual, unfair and discriminatory nature of these proposed new taxes and see them as quite different from any present form of taxation. That seems to me to be the key point. Nobody likes taxes. Senator Peter Rae made that point, and I agree with him. All reasonable people, however, know that taxation is necessary, but it is how they are taxed that is important. It is the realisation that these Bills we are debating would cause increased hardship and poverty to all those but the very wealthy that has led, I think, to the public reaction.

We are all members of Parliament, elected to take some notice of the people who put us here. I appeal to those members of the Government who will presently, I assume, vote for these Bills. They are going willingly, knowingly and directly against the interests and wishes of the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. That is a very serious matter. In doing so they have proposed some most ingeniously dishonest arguments. I cannot leave this debate without saying a few words about them.

It has been said that if the Government is prevented from increasing the cost of housing-that is, by not allowing sales tax to be imposed on building materials for a new house-by some mystery that will count against the interests of home buyers. It was no less a person than the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, who with every appearance of integrity uttered that whopper. It is a whopper. It is quite ridiculous. It has also been said that because the Government cannot get $300m in sales tax-we have said we will give it $100m; it only comes down to $200m on the actual necessities-it will not be able to give it back in the form of income tax cuts.

I am quite sure that the people of Australia are not so stupid that they would much rather not have the tax collected with all the attendant costs of doing so than have the Government take it from them and say: 'We have taken $200m from you, but the Australian Democrats have let it go so here is $200m back'. How stupid and inane is that sort of logic? The fatuous assumption that the Government is entitled to take money with one hand and give it back with the other is something that ordinary Australians ought to take with a grain of salt. It would be worth a good laugh, but what is not a laughing matter is the Government's considered statement that it will take and not give back. That, of course, is at the heart of the matter.

The lion's share comes from the tax on clothing and shoes. I want to deal with that. Senator Peter Rae mentioned that people will be taxed only 75c or 50c on a pair of shoes. I think it might be rather more than that but, whatever it is, $ 104m in a full year will come from the tax on clothing and shoes. That $104m is literally being wrung from the purses of people who cannot afford it. A sum of $ 96m would come out of the tax on building materials for new houses. Heaven knows what that cost will be by the time people finish paying off their mortgages. Do honourable senators know what the final cost will be to people with interest and so on? They will pay four to five times that by the time they finish paying off their mortgages. That $500 on every new house will be several thousand dollars that people will have to pay back over the period of their mortgages. Of course they would feel that. The tax also is dishonest. In my view it is dishonest for the reason that, whoever introduced the sales tax, the sales tax ingredient of a price should be listed in that price. In other words, it is not good enough that people should rather uneasily watch retail prices go up and up without realising that a considerable part of it is the sales tax ingredient. I hope that with all commodities we will get to the stage where the sales tax is stated as an element of cost so that people will notice what they are paying and where.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be a good idea, and then they couldn't blame us for more than one of the price rises put on.

—I am glad the honourable senator likes the idea. I commend it to him. The Government has every reason to be afraid of the consequences of even sponsoring these Bills. It will not be at all to the credit of the Government that the people of Australia will never pay them. The Government wants the people of Australia to pay them. I suggest that that is something the people of Australia will not forget easily or quickly. Note has already been taken of those Government members of the other place who have voted to pass these Bills. Note will also be taken of Government senators who vote to pass them here. They will have to account to their electorates for that over the next 18 months or so .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- This is the second time that the Senate has considered these Sales Tax Amendment Bills. I think it is fair to say that the issues have been extensively canvassed . If Senator Mason, who has just spoken, is right in saying that it costs $14, 000 per hour to run the sitting of the Senate, I wonder how those who have been listening to him for the past several minutes feel about the cost of the sort of speech that he has made and the complete misunderstanding of Government and the financing of Government responsibilities he appears to have.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let me comment on a number of technical questions on which comments were made by honourable senators during their contributions to the debate. It has been pointed out before, but it is worth saying again, that sales tax is a wholesale tax. It is a tax that is collected on a sale value which is, in the general run of cases, the amount for which the goods are sold at the last wholesale sale. The tax is charged by the wholesaler on the price which he charges his retail customers for the goods. The wholesaler accounts for the tax to the Taxation Office. As we have been talking about shoes, particularly children's shoes, perhaps by way of example I should say that a pair of shoes which is sold wholesale for $20 and retailed for $35 would, if these Bills become law, have a sales tax component of 50c in the retail price. When Senator Peter Rae and Senator Mason were speaking they concentrated on such issues. I think that the matter ought to be put into perspective. We had Senator Mason saying one minute that it is just a matter of peanuts and talking the next minute about the poverty of the whole of the Australian population. I think that the inconsistencies are rather remarkable.

There has been continued criticism of the Bills on the basis that they represent an indirect tax on foodstuffs through the proposals to tax certain wrapping materials. Senator Jones repeated this assertion in the first reading debate. That is not the case. I have previously given the Senate the example of a packet of breakfast cereal which is made up of a cardboard carton, a wax liner and the contents. Because of overriding exemptions in the sales tax law, such wax liners and cardboard cartons would remain exempt from tax as containers for exempt goods. I give that as just another example of some of the misunderstanding that has surrounded the Bills.

I would like to say something about the extensive campaign which has been directed against the proposal to tax books. There has been extensive debate and campaign on that issue. There have been hysterical advertisements along the lines: Where in the world is there a government that would tax knowledge? It has been asserted that this is the only government in the world that would do such a dreadful thing. In any proposal to broaden the tax bases, such as is contained in the present Bill, a wide base will be achieved and inequitable effects avoided only if the tax is imposed across the broad spectrum of goods commonly purchased.

A reasonable case can be made against the application of sales tax to books, as with its application to other categories of goods, when considered in isolation. It can be argued in each such case that the revenue resulting from the tax on that category of goods would be a relatively small amount. But the collection of tax, whether it be personal tax, sales tax or any other form of government impost, is made up of small amounts. It is made up of the aggregate of all the commodities in the areas in which that tax is applied. If one looks at a particular area one might say that it is peanuts, but if the Government were to forgo all the peanuts which it collects in taxes it would not have the revenue to pursue the very extensive role that Government is expected to play in this country. The inclusion of all such goods in any form of tax means that the Government can achieve a significant revenue base and apply a modest rate of tax at the same time. That is what has been attempted in these Bills.

Let us go back to the argument about the taxing of knowledge-the taxing of books. I remind those who have made an issue of this matter that most Western Euopean countries already impose a value added tax on books and many of the States in the United States of America impose sales taxes. To suggest that this is the first time that a tax on a book, a publication, a newspaper or anything of that sort is to be introduced in the free world is absolutely absurd. If the Democrat senators have convinced themselves on that issue they have--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do we say that?

—The Democrats have been supporting that lobby group. It has been extensively using the small group of Democrat senators in support of such advertisements which were placed and continued such misstatements. Taxation procedures in this country are being streamlined for the purposes of easing any potential administrative burdens on retail sales to exempt organisations and to ensure that exemption from sales tax can be claimed on such sales. That is something that ought to be said about books and publications in the closing statement of this debate because so much nonsense has been spoken and written about that.
—Does VAT apply to books?

— It could in any country that wished to have a broad range of commodities for which VAT is added. It has been suggested in the advertisements that this is the only country to apply a tax. To separate sales tax from company tax or any other tax that is applied to those who publish is to misstate the variety of ways in which companies are taxed on the commodities they produce for sale.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: — At the time the sitting of the Senate was suspended we were discussing the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [ No. 2] (1982). In the few minutes that I had spoken I pointed out some of the matters raised by honourable senators during the debate that had to be clarified . I now say that Government senators have carefully documented in their speeches the inconsistency, hypocrisy and the broken pledges of the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats on this matter. There have been a lot of speeches and I do not intend to go through all of those matters again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor party and the Democrat senators have explained why all their previous statements on the role of the Senate and money Bills did not, in fact, mean what every intelligent voter assumed they meant. Senator Evans in particular has made a series of speeches which would provide a fascinating study to any students of politics or any of those who are interested in constitutional matters. Little did Government senators think that one day, after all of Senator Evans's years of raging on the Australian Broadcasting Commission system, the lecture circuit and elsewhere that we would have the same Senator Evans lecturing us on the necessity for the Senate to reject a money Bill. Honourable senators will recall how he referred to the Democrats as political Cliff Richardses. I suppose that if we are going to draw analogies we could look at the twists and turns in his own explanations to show how quickly he can turn from a self-styled legal authority into, perhaps, a constitutional Chubby Checker. Senator Evans's contribution to constitutional reform can perhaps be viewed in that light in the future because if things do not mean what he said they mean, then I wonder how people can evaluate what is said in the course of debate on constitutional reform.

The Democrat and ALP senators have argued on the one hand that the effects of these Bills are so catastrophic that they would justify the use of the Senate to reject a money Bill. When one listened to the speeches it was obvious that that argument could not be sustained as a reason for rejecting a money Bill. So we have the Democrats proposing to amend the Bills, suggesting that if we take out this and that, then they will pass them. That, of course, is something that it is not within their constitutional power to do as senators. I think we ought to remind them that if they are going to reject the Bills, then they can do so but it is the Government that draws up the Bills. If the Democrats do not choose to pass the Bills, let them reject the Bills, as they obviously intend to do. Senator Evans was reduced to phrases like 'small but undoubtedly cumulative effect', 'significant marginal effect' and so on. Phrases such as these make one wonder how sincerely he holds a principle. If a principle can be compromised for significant marginal impact we wonder what the real principle that is supposed to be upheld really means.

I think at the same time it was said that the Budget effects were unimportant. No one should underestimate the consequences of the failure to pass these Bills. The passage of these Bills would have increased the revenue of the Australian Government by about $330m in a full year. That is not insignificant, whatever figures Senator Mason likes to put out. An amount of $330m in a full year of government revenue is a substantial amount of revenue. There can be no doubt that the action by the ALP and the Democrats who have planned a strategy attacks an important part of the Budget that was presented. It makes it more difficult to lighten the personal tax load. I do not think that anyone here would argue that there is not widespread community support for reducing personal income tax. The action of Opposition senators must inevitably increase the pressure to reduce government services or make it less possible to reduce personal income tax. I think State governments would have little to thank Opposition senators for in this case because by rejecting these tax Bills, State revenues will be reduced by some $27m next year. On a full year basis the total cost to the States will be around $70m. Bearing in mind the claims of the States on the public purse no one would argue that $70m is insignificant as far as the States' revenues are concerned.

The Democrats themselves have recognised that the refusal to pass money Bills introduces considerable new uncertainties into the governmen of this country. A number of speakers have talked on this subject; some of them have made specific statements. Senator Mason has been, perhaps, the most eloquent on this matter. He stated a number of things last August. I do not intend to go through all of them because a number of honourable senators have drawn attention to them. But last August he said:
. . . the consequences of the Senate meddling in or unilaterally rewriting a Budget seem to us too horrifying to contemplate.
Senator Mason asked a rhetorical question in that Budget debate speech:
. . . Can we mess around with the Budget a little and if so, how much?
He then stated:

Clearly, to reject Bills which would cost the Government a billion dollars would be going too far. . . It really comes back to a matter of degree, does it not? Clearly the Senate has the right to alter the Budget a little. It has an equal right to alter it a great deal.

I do not know where the logic of that assertion led. Senator Mason said on national radio the next day, I think, that the Democrats would not attempt to block the sales tax Bills in February. We will just wait to see when we take the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

— In February, March or April. The Bills have been around since August. I do not think one month matters any more to Senator Mason. I invite honourable senators to contrast the statements that have been made as an illustration of how flexible the principles of the Democrats have become. They become very flexible when at one time they can say that the consequences are too horrifying to contemplate. At a later time when it suits their purpose they can then do something absolutely contrary to what they had said was too horrifying to contemplate.
—If you are so concerned, have an election on the issue. You can have a double dissolution any time you like.

— I should imagine that if the Bills are not passed, if they are rejected in this place, they will become the first Bills that have been rejected by both Houses. In accordance with the Constitution, a double dissolution could be sought. There are some remarks by Senator Macklin that perhaps ought to be put on the record again. He had something to say on these matters.
—We have heard it all before about 10 times.

— Yes, honourable senators have heard it all. They do not like hearing it again. It is all right for honourable senators to make their speeches but they do not like hearing them again. Senator Macklin said:

SPEECH.PARA: Irrespective of the potential electoral backlash to the Democrats, we will not follow the Liberal and Labor Parties in breaking election pledges. We could hardly claim to keep either of the old parties honest unless we are honest ourselves.
Senator Macklin was quoted in today's Bulletin-I presume correctly as stating:

There was a difference between a government breaking the promises made during an election campaign and the 'change in tactics' the Democrats adopted once it became apparent that the opposition to the sales tax ran very deep in the electorate.

One will note from those two statements that broken promises merely become a change in tactics. The electoral backlash which was not important last September when considering the value of principle is now used as a justification for a change of heart. If Senator Macklin or any other honourable senator wishes to make a contribution in this place then the contribution which he makes to political jargon will, at least, be noteworthy. I think that where broken promises merely become a change in tactics it is probably on par with a lot of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —It's nowhere near it. We wouldn't even match you in broken promises. We are not in the same race.

— The Opposition does not get many opportunities to put its promises into effect. That is why it can make them so easily. When it gets those very rare occasions to put promises into effect it does not do much about it.
—And you will not let us do it again either.
— No, we will not let you do it again either.
—Tell us about your mandate.

— I thought I might tell honourable senators a little about personal income tax relief and the effect and strategy of the Budget. I thought that might be better. The Democrats and the ALP seem to be determined to frustrate and set back the course of personal income tax relief. Every attempt by this Government to bring about personal income tax relief has been fought by the ALP and the Democrats. I do not think anyone in the chamber needs reminding how reductions in Government expenditure have been ceaselessly attacked by the ALP and the Democrats. Indeed, Senator Button believes that one is able to build a career of pleading for lobby groups for increases in Government services. One way to run the work that one does in this place is to respond to every lobby group that comes to one. Another way is to have some sort of policy and to stick with it. If the public sector's share of community resources cannot be held back, there is no way in which total taxation, whatever form it might be in-whether it is what Senator Mason or what a government wants- can be reduced. For instance, the ALP's spending program-if we are talking about promises, there are plenty of them there-cannot be financed in any other way except by increased taxation-higher taxation. The shadow Treasurer has admitted this in his statements.
—Stop all the accountants and their lawyers and their tax avoidance schemes.
— I think continuing the efforts we have made with regard to tax avoidance is a responsibility of government.
—These people rob the taxpayers.
—Order! Senator Gietzelt. Senator Guilfoyle has the floor.

—This Government has said repeatedly that a broadening of the indirect tax base would enhance the capacity to give personal tax relief at the appropriate time. That was one of the steps we were taking in the Budget of last year to put us in a position to pay our way with the Government programs that we have and to provide an opportunity to give personal tax relief. This matter was referred by Senator Peter Rae when he spoke earlier today. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) pointed out, the ALP and the Democrats are pursuing a course of preserving a taxation system which places too heavy a burden on personal income tax. The Treasurer has stated in many of the things that he has said as part of his responsibility that people who call for personal tax relief have some responsibility to say where the money is to come from-by an expansion of the deficit or by reduction in expenditure or by some change in the taxation mix. That is the way we are going to have personal tax cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: If changes in the taxation mix are to be rejected by the Opposition, that removes one of the ways in which the Government can give personal tax relief. We are left either with inflating the deficit, adding to the deficit, or with having to reduce Government expenditure. Certainly the reduction in Government expenditure is criticised by the Opposition at every opportunity, however irrelevant a program might have become. The Democrats and the Labor Party presumably are not calling for further spending cuts. However, by this action they are inhibiting the capacity of the Government to give personal taxation relief. Maybe throughout these long months of talking about sales tax amendments there is some irony that would be obvious to many observers. Yesterday the Opposition brought forward a matter of public importance attacking the Government for breaking promises. Yet it is all too easily said in the summarised quote from Senator Button, when he said: 'The issue is primarily one of credibility'. It is not the credibility of the Government which is at stake in these Budget Bills which are before the Senate. It is the credibility of the ALP-on the string of promises it has made, on the commitments that it makes and on the constitutional statements that it makes-and also the credibility of the Democrats, on the promises that were made by them.

These sales tax Bills are an integral part of the Budget of last August. They have had several months of political somersaults and obstructions in this place. They are before us again now. I think we ought to test them at the vote. I do not think the handling of them has done any credit to the Opposition in this Senate. I think we ought now, at the completion of the second reading debate, wish the Bills a speedy passage.

—I guess I have to draw a picture for some people. I said that Senator Evans had drawn my attention to the fact that part of what I quoted from a speech made by him-that is, Senator Evans-on 20 August 1981 in the Senate did not do justice to him in that I should have quoted further. Therefore, I drew attention to page 148 of Senate Hansard of 20 August 1981. As well as the part which I quoted, I go on to say that Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not making a long speech; I am simply explaining what is crucial. It is crucial to the explanation and it is crucial to the distinction that needs to be made and understood that whenever I or anyone else has used those kinds of expressions in all the debates that have taken place since 1974 and 1975 we have been using them in the context of the events of 1974 and 1975 when what was in issue was a particular category of Bills-namely, in 1974 the Supply Bills and in 1975 Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which were on any view crucial to the continued survival, the continued existence of the Government of the day. That was the context in which that discussion has always taken place; that is the context in which I and others have used those expressions. The relevant issue then as now is whether or not the money Bills, the Budget Bills-whatever sort of Bills are in question-are relevant to the survival of a government. DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON GOVERNMENT CLOTHING AND ORDNANCE FACTORIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Senator Martyr:
That the Senate take note of the report.
Upon which Senator Button had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate expresses its concern with the method of implementation of Government policies and, in particular:

(a) the failure of the Government to respond and act on various reports of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence relating to defence procurement, Australian defence priorities and Australian defence industries;
(b) its failure to provide modern guns and missiles for the ships of the Royal Australian Navy;
(c) allowing the Government Ordnance Factories to run down through lack of work , while ordering weapons from overseas which could have been manufactured in those factories;

(d) failing to secure adequate guarantees on cost, delivery, offsets, Australian industry participation and technology transfers for defence material bought overseas, particularly in the case of the Leopard tank and M198 155 mm Howitzer programs;
(e) a lack of planning in the aerospace, munitions and ship building industries ;

(f) the failure of the Government to give adequate weight to questions of social policy, including employment, and the consequences in social terms for the economy of the City of Bendigo if the Ordnance Factory is sold, or closed; and
(g) the failure to relate Government policies in relation to the Ordnance Factories with other policies relating to industry support,
and calls on the Government to respond and expand the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo under its present management'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke on this matter I completely dissociated myself from the report of the Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, should either be sold or closed. As honourable senators will be aware, the decision to sell or close the Bendigo Ordnance Factory was taken by the infamous razor gang, otherwise known as the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which reported on 30 April 1981. The Government then restated its philosophical belief that ' activities of a commercial kind were generally best performed in the private sector'. This, to put it bluntly, is a lousy argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Few reasonable people would not argue that some things are better done by private industry. The Government has completely failed to demonstrate that ordnance manufacture is necessarily one of them. If ordnance manufacture in Australia were a field of engineering which appealed to Australian entrepreneurs I suggest they would have entered it long ago. There were opportunities during World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War for private companies to enter the field of ordnance manufacture. They did not, and they did not do so for very good reasons. They believed that it would not be profitable. Nothing that I have heard or read leads me to believe that Australian entrepreneurs have changed their opinion. The chance of private enterprise running the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, profitably without defence orders is absolutely zero. It is just not on . Without defence orders no one can operate the factory profitably. With them the Government can run it just as efficiently as private enterprise.

Honourable senators may think that Government involvement in ordnance manufacture in Australia is unique. In fact, the reverse is the case. Of course there are private arms manufacturers around the world, but most of these have been in business for many years. Their knowledge is highly specialised and they export around the world. I refer to companies such as Bofors, Oerlikon and Vickers. These are well known. It must be recognised that in almost every country with an arms industry there is a close relationship between the manufacturer and the government if not outright government participation. This is only natural. Individuals do not, as a rule, buy 155 millimetre howitzers. Governments are generally the only customers and therefore there tends to be an incestuous relationship between governments and private contractors.

The reason for government involvement is very clear. Arms manufacture is too important to be left to the vagaries of private enterprise. Nations have strategic interests, and the most important is survival. Many countries perceive that this interest is served by having a great degree of control over the weapons which arm their forces.
