In the lifetime of most honourable senators, Australia has been placed in a situation where supplies have been cut off from traditional manufacturers. If it had not been in the interests of our allies during the last world war Australia would have been left for dead. If private industry cannot or will not enter the ordnance business-I have made the point that private industry will not enter the ordnance business without firm contracts from the Government-the Government must. To do otherwise would be an abrogation of the Government's basic responsibility to the defence of this country.

The majority report found that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo possessed few industrial processes necessary to defence production and that most tasks performed at Bendigo could equally be undertaken at other government factories or by industry generally. This is demonstrably misleading. Firstly, the OFB has a number of industrial processes necessary to defence production. For example, officials of the Western Gear Corporation in the United States described the factory as having a greater capacity to manufacture gears for naval ships than the rest of Australian industry combined. A number of other technical processes undertaken at the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo are unique. Given time and capital, anything that is being done at Bendigo could be done elsewhere. This is not disputed. But why should taxpayers bear the burden of shifting what is already at Bendigo to Maribrynong, Sydney or elsewhere when Bendigo is performing satisfactorily?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not talking about the taxpayers' burden at the moment?

—I am indeed. Even more important than the cost of shifting the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo to some other location, for reasons that have not been established, is the fact that a factory cannot operate without skilled people. Factories are not just machinery. They are essentially made up of the technicians, skilled people and professional engineers who run them. Machinery without these skills is so much junk. If the skills that are presently and demonstrably at Bendigo were dispersed, for reasons that have not been established, I suggest it would be nothing short of a scandal. The factory has repeatedly demonstrated that it can match overseas production and quality. It has a very good industrial relations record. It has a staff as efficient as staff ceilings and low orders have allowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The ordnance factory was described in the majority report as being unimportant and not vital to present defence requirements. If that be true now, surely it was equally true in the 1960s when Bendigo was subject to two government inquiries. No decision was made during the 1960s to sell the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. If it was not sold then it is surely a million times more important that it be maintained now when the dangers of a third world war have increased tremendously. The Government cannot guarantee or even reasonably predict that Australia will not be involved in a defence emergency within the next five years . I challenge the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) to state otherwise. The Ordnance Factory contains a number of facilities and skills which would be absolutely essential in war time and which could not be re-established in Australia in any reasonable time, certainly not in a period of under five years. If an emergency arose, Australia would be absolutely dependent on foreign governments for such essential things as shafting and gearing for ships and heavy guns for the army and for other vital equipment. The supply of many of these vital arms for our defence forces has proved very unreliable in peace time . I will illustrate that with a couple of specific examples. Only the fates can predict how less reliable these supply lines would be in an emergency or in war time when our allies were under great stress themselves. To rebuild the factory at Bendigo from scratch-there is evidence to support this-would cost about $200m and take, as I have said, at least five years.

Let me turn to the relocation argument. The majority report claims that the defence works at Bendigo could be relocated in a comparatively short time in other munitions factories. Yet the Committee received no evidence that Maribyrnong, the only other factory mentioned in this context, could, without any problems, accommodate the extra plant and machinery if it were transferred from Bendigo. Maribyrnong already has space problems, it has difficulty in recruiting and keeping trained staff and it is built on reclaimed land which probably would be insufficiently stable to house some of the heavy equipment from the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. In any case, the expense of moving certain equipment cannot be justified and was not justified according to the Department of Industry and Commerce. The majority report concluded that commercial work would have to pay its way or, alternatively, more defence orders would have to be placed with the factory. With the second contention I can only agree. More orders should be placed with the factory. But the nature of the commercial work undertaken precludes the first option. Considerable evidence was presented that the factory is a regional centre of engineering excellence. I believe that it is appropriate for a government factory to undertake research for the benefit of commercial companies along similar lines to that undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Few Australian companies can afford to do very much applied research and it is not unreasonable that this should be undertaken at government factories.

Lastly, I turn to the social question. The Committee found that the Government had no social responsibility to maintain the factory in its present form. This may or may not be true but the Government undoubtedly has a social responsibility to plan the development of industry in the Bendigo region to absorb those people who would be displaced if the factory were closed. Local organisations and individuals who gave evidence to the Committee almost unanimously agreed that the closure of the factory would have a grave social effect on the area. It was suggested that unemployment could well rise by 50 per cent within a few months. The city and the surrounding area already have a very serious unemployment problem with up to 30 per cent of people unemployed in places such as Castlemaine. The area is amongst the worst in the country for unemployment. Without the prospects of stable employment at the factory, many more young people would undoubtedly drift to the city. The local housing market is already badly depressed and it will be savaged if hundreds more people are forced to leave the area.

The majority report concluded that commercial ideas and philosophies introduced in the factory would have a great potential to enhance Bendigo's future and Australian defence capabilities if private industry took over. Although in principle I agree with the idea that private entrepreneurs are often more imaginative and make better use of resources, this is not necessarily the case. The most important question is: What would be the future of the Ordnance Factory , Bendigo, if it were sold to private industry? The fact of the matter is that engineering shops all over Australia are underutilised at present. The Government's disastrous economic policies mean there is considerable overcapacity in general heavy engineering right through the country. This is unlikely to be changed in the near future.

In this environment I can see no point why any large engineering company would want to buy the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. The unique equipment is too specialised to be profitable and the non-unique equipment already exists in more than adequate quantities around the country. The equipment that is an exception to this would, I submit, be much more likely to be stripped and sold to individuals once the factory was turned over to private enterprise. The vague assurances that such important and critical items of defence would not be disposed of were given by the Department of Industry and Commerce during evidence but that evidence was totally unconvincing and unsatisfactory. The only way to prevent asset stripping if the factory were sold to private enterprise would be for the Government to retain ownership of it and then to lease the equipment. This option was specifically ignored by my colleagues even though it is in fact widely practised in the United States of America.

The Committee recommends that the factory should retain certain defence contracts presently unique to its operations such as the 105 millimetre light gun project. The irony and the inconsistency of this contention surely has not escaped people who think about the matter and surely will not escape this Senate . On the one hand it is contended that the factory has no unique equipment and on the other hand the problems of maintaining a capacity to build 105 millimetre light guns is admitted. If I so vehemently oppose the sale or closure of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory what then, in the Democrats view, is the future for it? Undoubtedly the factory possesses a combination of equipment and skills which make it a vital asset to this country and unique to Australia. It is the only factory in Australia which without modification can manufacture and maintain heavy navy guns which are now required for the follow-on destroyer program. It should not be sold because of the risk of asset stripping and the dispersal of staff. Its sale would undoubtedly complicate such projects as the manufacture of the 105 millimetre guns. Above all, it should not be sold because, in fact, it is a resource of national importance. I therefore recommend that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, should remain as a Government owned and operated concern.

It is evident that the organisation of the munitions supply division as part of the Department of Industry and Commerce has been a disaster. The division should be reorganised, preferably on similar lines to those of Royal Ordnance Factories in Britain. It should be removed from the control of the Department of Industry and Commerce and given the status of a publicly owned corporation operating as far as possible on commercial lines but in close liaison with the Defence Department. It is also abundantly evident that insufficient work has been done to promote the sale of Australian arms and military equipment overseas. A defence sales organisation has not been set up for the purpose but undoubtedly there is a lot of scope for such an organisation to promote the sale of Australian produced arms in other countries.

Lastly, it must be recommended that the procurement procedures of the Department of Defence be streamlined. Evidence showed that the time allowed for contractors to manufacture goods and equipment for defence was frequently less than 25 per cent of the period of the whole procurement program. For long lead times such as Bendigo requires for the manufacture of important naval ordnance, that sort of time scale is just not good enough. It seems foolish for Australia to get out of manufacture simply because the defence bureaucracy cannot set its house in order. On behalf of the Australian Labor Party, Senator Button circulated an amendment. Paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e) contain amendments previously circulated by me on behalf of the Democrats. We support the amendments of the Opposition. I will speak briefly to four of the clauses in the amendment. In relation to clause (b) the amendment states:
but the Senate expresses its concern with the method of implementation of Government policies and, in particular:
(b) its failure to provide modern guns and missiles for the ships of the Royal Australian Navy;

Only one of the ships of the Royal Australian Navy has a modern short range missile or gun capable of engaging a surface skimming surface-to-surface missile . The Bendigo Ordnance Factory could build such a gun.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this amendment have to do with the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo?

—It has everything to do with it. The Ordnance Factory has already quoted on the OTO-Melara gun which is a modern naval gun having the capability to shoot down surface skimming guided missiles. The factory has quoted competitively, with satisfactory delivery times compared with overseas suppliers of this sort of weapon. This is an important point. These surface skimming missiles are now the predominant weapon in naval warfare. Their impact has been as great as the development of the long range naval gun or the self- propelled torpedo was at the turn of this century. The Soviet Navy has practised their use and deployment for 20 years. The Western navies are only beginning to come to grips with their intricacies. The Soviets have created a large and complex communications system to co-ordinate the use of anti-ship missiles fired from aircraft, surface ships or submarines. It is very likely that in the first few minutes of the next war the Soviets will attempt a high seas Pearl Harbour. The 5 inch guns of the Perth class guided missile destroyers and the 4.5 inch guns of the River class escorts were designed well before this threat in naval warfare materialised. The efficiency of the fire-control systems for these guns against small targets on the horizon line is open to very grave doubt. Also it is understood that our ships do not have shells with modern proximity fuses which can be fired at ultra low level targets. Thus for the time being our ships -the front line of our Navy-do not have modern guns capable of defending themselves against surface skimming missiles. The one manufacturing capability we have in this country to produce such guns has been recommended by the Government to be sold.

SPEECH.PARA: Will the new frigates-the River class escorts-be equipped with Harpoon missiles from the date of commissioning? The Minister for Defence has declined to answer a question on notice which sought to find out how many Harpoon missiles the Australian defence forces currently have. The position was made clear by Rear Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot, Chief of Defence Force Staff, when he told a Press Conference last year that Harpoons were not being procured for specific platforms but were being pooled and issued for training purposes as demanded. An examination of the Budget Papers would lead one to the conclusion that we probably have not purchased more than about 30 Harpoon missiles. The Chilean and Royal navies have converted ships which are similar to our own River class to carry surface to surface missiles; we have no such plans in Australia. The River class frigates perhaps should be renamed the 'sitting duck' class. Recently, we purchased a new aircraft carrier. We purchased this aircraft carrier without any aircraft. This can only be described as analogous to purshasing a battleship without guns. It is a fact that that ship, without its short take-off and landing aircraft, will be virtually useless in an all-out war situation.

I conclude by stressing the fact that, as set out in the amendments, there are serious and grave problems associated with our armed forces and particularly our naval defence. A problem has already become apparent in our attempt to buy important arms equipment overseas. I could instance the problem that we have already experienced with 155 millimetre howitzer. That equipment was purchased from the United States of America. The order was given to that country when the equipment was capable of being produced competitively by the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. That order was placed in the United States essentially because the delivery time was somewhat better than that quoted by the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. After the order was placed, great pressure was placed on the manufacturing capability of the United States in an attempt to build up its defence equipment. It gives me no pleasure to tell the Senate that right now the delivery time that was quoted by the Ordnance Factory towards the end of this year will now be exceeded by a delivery time from the United States at least three years hence. In other words, it will be another three years before we can get heavy artillery for the Army from our closest ally as there is already a strain on its defence manufacturing capabilities and a need to build up its requirements quickly. If this sort of problem can arise now before there is any immediate world emergency or threat of a war, how much greater will the problem be when such a situation arises?

TALK.START.PARA: —It makes a fallacy of the concept of Fortress Australia, doesn't it?

—It does. We are about to consider the selling of, or running the risk of the dispersal of, a vital manufacturing enterprise at Bendigo. The Australian Democrats call on the Senate to take note of the serious consequences of such an action and to register its disapproval to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the motion that the Senate take note of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on its inquiring into the future of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. Senator Siddons has raised a number of issues which one feels spontaneously inclined to challenge. But I think it is probably appropriate that I refer myself to the remarks that I intended to make and, inasmuch as the debate will be continued, perhaps deal with those issues at that later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should refer to those matters which were before the Committee at the time when it contemplated the various aspects of its terms of reference. All the members of the Committee directed their attention towards three main areas of concern: Australia's defence procurement needs as they affected the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, the economic considerations as they affected the factory, and the social and economic effects our determinations may have had on the Bendigo region. Primarily, in my view at least-I think it was a consensus of the Committee-there were three headings at which we could look: The first was the sale of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, as a going concern; secondly, the retention of the factory in the hands of the Government; and, thirdly, ultimately its eventual closure. Naturally, inasmuch as the factory undertakes not only defence work but also commercial work, there are a number of variations to these options. However, these were the broad headings under which we chose to work.

I am pleased to say that there were many substantial matters upon which the Committee unanimously agreed, not the least being that the factory could not continue to proceed as it presently stands and operates under the existing arrangements. There was one real conflict between the four members of the Committee. I am pleased to be able to say at this point that there was harmony, good will and a co-operative sense of determination in arriving at our final determinations. Regrettably, towards the very end of the inquiry, two members of the Committee took off at tangents-at least in my view-and found themselves subject to variations other than the substantial facts before them. But perhaps what was in conflict was the interpretation of the facts that were presented to the Committee in evidence. I think it is also true to say that there was no lack of good will in seeking to find common ground, not only on the substantial evidence that was before us in terms of the general course that the Committee should take, but also to ensure that consideration should be given to all matters and accommodated in a proper and reasonable way.

I turn first to defence. The major issues really are whether the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, plays an integral and vital part in the defence procurement process within Australia or, perhaps as Senator Siddons has said, whether it should in the future. In other words, is it excess to need or does it have a unique capacity that is vital to Australia's future needs? Will that unique capacity be reduced or lost by the factory being sold to private enterprise or finally and ultimately, if necessary, closed down and its rare and unique capacity being transferred to other government ordinance factories such as the Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong? As the conclusions contained in the Committee's report demonstrate, it was my view and the view of the Chairman, Senator Martyr, that the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, is not an integral and vital part of Australia's defence procurement process and that that so modest part of the factory which would appear for the moment to be undertaking unique work in Australia can be readily relocated in other Australian ordnance factories or duplicated at the very least within the private enterprise sector.

Firstly, it ought to be clearly understood that only two activities that that factory presently undertakes would be in some respects difficult to transfer. The first, of course, relates to the 4.5 inch naval gun mountings and the second is the turning of ships' propeller shafts. In the case of the 4.5 inch naval gun mountings the difficulty in transferring the activity lies in the building space , the height, the lifting requirements for the mountings and other considerations which are not readily available elsewhere for the time being. However, as evidence before the Committee has clearly demonstrated, these guns are fitted to destroyers which will end their lives in the late 1980s or the early 1990s. The only real difficulty in respect of the lathe which turns the propeller shafts is the cost of relocation. It cost $1.7m to introduce and bed down and it has been installed in the factory only recently. However, it perhaps ought to be recalled that the moment the factory appeared to be up for sale, following the announcement by the Government, there were inquiries from the private sector as to whether that piece of equipment was to be included in the terms of reference of the sales. All other present activities could be transferred into the private sector or to other Government ordnance factories. In my view to that extent Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, is not vital or unique to the defence needs of Australia.

It has been argued in evidence that the factory has the capacity to manufacture a number of items that are currently being purchased or ordered from overseas for our defence forces. I do not question that there are certain components of such defence orders that the factory could and is competent to manufacture. However, I question two matters: Firstly, whether those components can be produced and procured at a competitive price and, secondly, whether they can be manufactured within a reasonable time frame as set down by the defence forces. I should perhaps be on record as saying that I am not so patriotic as to say that I concur with the proposition that we have out on the field a gun of some sort which is antiquated and highly expensive but which has upon it as its only claim to fame a stamp which simply reads: 'Made in Bendigo'. Of course, having built the machine in Australia, we cannot afford to manufacture the ammunition that is required to make it an effective component for our defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we have the capacity to build up-to-date guns? You are talking about antiquated guns.

—I am saying that in terms of the time frame required a gun would be antiquated when it was acquired firstly because of its being manufactured at Bendigo; and, secondly, because the cost would be so prohibitive , particularly with respect to a number of components of guns which the factory is presently seeking to acquire.
—But we cannot do it in Australia?

—We can do it in Australia eventually. We can do anything in Australia eventually, all being equal and with the will of God. Taking the second issue first, on a number of occasions the factory has found that even if it has been able to compete with overseas suppliers at the right price it has not been able to provide the equipment in the time required. In defence of the factory and as an excuse for the factory operating at less than 50 per cent, and only 39 per cent of that 50 per cent being on defence work, the Professional Engineers and Officers Association claims that the actual manufacturing process constitutes only between 5 per cent and 10 per cent of the defence procurement process. It has sought to validate its claim by producing a picture plan of the steps which are involved from the identification by the defence forces of the need for a new ordnance to the completion of delivery to the service of the first of these pieces of equipment. A typical piece of equipment is illustrated in the Association's document, which is incorporated in our report, but no time scale is given.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the time frame and the evidence would certainly seem to make a valid point about the complexity and the length of the decision-making process, about which I make no comment, it is certainly misleading and decidedly inaccurate to suggest that only 5 per cent to 10 per cent of the procurement time is spent on manufacture. Perhaps the most contemporary, reasonable and proper example that I can give is the recent decision to manufacture in Australia the new 105 millimetre howitzer gun which was initiated in about 1972. Selection of the weapon was announced recently and the Australian prototype manufacturing phase is expected to lead to an announced decision to approve the first production phase in 1984. The production which ensues could provide the Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong, and a commercially owned ordnance factory at Bendigo with 1.85 million man hours of work load over the period to 1996. Thus from the point of view of initiation of early inquiries production time would, in the example I have examined, represent about 50 per cent of the total and 80 per cent if taken from the point of selection of the weapon. I think it goes to demonstrate that some of the evidence which was provided to the Committee was far from accurate and precise.

Successive governments have been seeking to divide defence purchases between local manufacturers and overseas purchasers, taking into consideration such factors as retaining defence skills and capabilities in Australia, the cost, equipment numbers, repeat orders, patents, future requirements and Australia's ability to supply the item. Given the obvious limits of the defence budget and the requirements of Australia's defence forces, these are all matters which should properly be considered. Much has been made of the fact that Australia is to purchase the 155 millimetre howitzer gun overseas rather than have it made in Australia. Dismissing any other considerations to which I have just referred, I quote Mr Roberts, the Bendigo factory manager, in response to a question from Senator Siddons. Senator Siddons asked:

I refer to this contentious question of the availability of work which should or should not be done at Bendigo. I have asked a specific question on this, but perhaps you could answer in general terms at this stage. Let us take, for example, the 155 millimetre Howitzer. Would the manufacture of one of these Howitzers put very many man hours into the factory?
Mr Roberts replied:

One Howitzer is not very much. The tooling up would be the extensive part of the work. The actual work on the Howitzer would probably be only one-thirtieth or perhaps a fiftieth of the amount of work to tool up to make one Howitzer.
Senator Siddons asked:
The tooling up is the problem?
Mr Roberts answered:
The tooling up is the costly part of the exercise. The tooling up costs can be multiplied, say between 30 and 40 times each one.
On the same item, Senator Button asked the following question:
Was it your view that the Ordnance Factory could produce it at roughly equivalent costs to any competitors?
Mr Roberts said:
No, I am afraid I could not claim that because we would be tooling up for a very small quantity, therefore our capital costs and the tooling up costs would have to be borne in by a small number.

Of course, there are only 36 of these guns to be made. Here lies the problem. It has been suggested time and time again that we should be making these 155 millimetre Howitzer guns within Australia. Without taking up too much time tonight, I say that there have been suggestions that the acquisition of those guns has been delayed for all sorts of other reasons in the United States of America because of previous demands on United States production for that country 's own program. The fact of the matter is that the acquisition of that gun has been delayed by only six months and it has been delayed only because of the problems of manufacture in that country. There is much criticism of the fact that the equipment was not built in Australia but to do so, particularly for a small quantity with no prospects of a repeat order, would have made the cost per unit absolutely prohibitive. Of course, we can fill the factory. We can fill it up to capacity as long as we like and as hard as we like; the only question is the amount of money we as a government are prepared to spend filling up an incompetent, incapable, inefficient, over-expensive factory. It makes an enormous dent in the defence budget as a whole. I believe that a balance has to be achieved between competing demands for the defence dollar. I quote Mr Wood, the Acting First Assistant Secretary to the Department of Industry and Commerce. He said:

There is a continuing pressure in all fields of the Defence outlay. The Defence Science Organisation, the factory organisation, the Service equipment votes and the Service operating expenses all compete for whatever money is available. It all comes together in the five-year program process and is argued in committee before the Government.

If you are to pay a penalty to make something of considerable proportions in Australia you will end up with less equipment as a total being purchased and less ability to make things. The new tactical fighter project, for example, will have a considerable penalty for doing work in Australia, but it is debated and the level of that penalty is a matter which will be decided by the Government in the end.

It is not only a question of the best utilisation of the defence dollar, but it is also a question of the total utilisation of the dollar within the total Budget. This is the question that we have to ask ourselves: Do we want the luxury of making equipment in Australia or do we want to contemplate aspects such as building more homes for those people who cannot afford homes-those in need? Of course the real problem is simply that Australia does not have a demand for enough volume equipment to justify building them over here to reduce the component and the unit costs. When countries such as America are able to build tens of thousands of the units and we require perhaps 20 or 30-odd, there is no way we can practically compete. I suspect that perhaps the Committee was unanimously of the view that Australia should have a capacity to make certain items in Australia and that certain skills should be maintained in this country. However, the point on which Senator Martyr and I differed from other members of the community was whether Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, was such a place for this capacity to reside, considering all other factors. We are of the view that if the capacity is to remain at Bendigo it ought to be properly in the hands of private enterprise, put on a commercial basis and integrated with other commercial work at the factory. The factory would then be capable of producing. Alternatively, of course, if the very worst comes to pass, the capacity of the factory ought to be transferred and integrated with other skills presently utilised at Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong. That would make a very substantial saving in tax and would ensure no loss of skills for Australia.

The argument was put by the Professional Engineers and Officers Association that Ordnance Factory, Maribyrnong, should be rationalised to Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. However, dismissing all other considerations, the cost of that proposal is prohibitive and does not stand the test of any reasonable economic argument. The first report of the Special Advisor on the Future Development of the Australian Defence Production Factories presented in 1981 indicated that the estimated cost to transfer essential capacity from Bendigo to Maribyrnong was $1 .5m. The reverse was $60m. The Professional Engineers and Officers Association also claimed that the Maribyrnong factory was being phased out and that the forging aspect was obsolete. As I understand the situation, it is being refurbished and will continue well into the near future.

Two other arguments against the rationalisation of Bendigo to Maribyrnong were put by the Factory Area Committee. It suggested that there were staffing difficulties and that there were some strategic weaknesses. In this time of high unemployment and given the mobility of the average member of the community, I find this aspect a remarkable revelation. In respect of the second matter I would have thought that Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, being a prime or secondary target in a time of conflict, would be a highly unlikely proposition. Numerous reports over the years have commented that it was not desirable that the factory continue as it presently does. For many years it has gone along far below capacity, and successive governments have done very little to correct it. What Senator Button said last night was ever so true; it is an indictment on all governments that absolutely nothing has been done about it. In fact in 1980-81 its total utilisation was less than 50 per cent of normal capacity which, by definition, is one shift at full shift capacity. Of that, only 36 per cent was related to defence work. We can say that for one full shift capacity at that factory only 18 per cent of that time was spent on defence work.

I put it to honourable senators that with a factory which employs 650 people, with a replacement cost of capital equipment of approximately $200m, I find it very difficult to justify the maintenance of that factory as it remains at present. The balance of the work-50 per cent of it-was commercial work and the rest was done for other government departments. Certainly it is very hard to justify the commercial basis by any standards. As the majority report indicates, the type of commercial work being undertaken was of a one-off, complex, heavy engineering nature, and tendering was done on the basis, presumably, as I understand it, of being able to recover some part of the cost of the undertaking . As the report also indicates, the work tendered for was not particularly attractive to private enterprise. I refer honourable senators to the evidence provided to the Committee, and particularly to the evidence of Mr Roberts, the factory manager. The evidence states:

Mr Roberts-Generally speaking, that is the work that other people do not find attractive. From the engineering manager's point of view it is quite interesting , but from the economic point of view it is quite expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are really saying is that you do work nobody else wants, primarily.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Roberts-In many cases yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that? If you are trying to supplement defence work with commercial work, and you are having problems with your defence work, why compound the problem by going into another area which will be uneconomic?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Roberts-This gives us a chance to up our art.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a luxury, is it not?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Roberts-And to improve our technology. It gives us a chance to up the art. Yes I think it is proving that this is one of the problems we are facing. It is expensive.

However, notwithstanding the fact that much of the work was not attractive to private enterprise, the tendering process guaranteed that factory a 9 per cent success rate. In view of the departmental evidence that the factory felt inhibited in tendering for commercial work, it is worth noting that notwithstanding the factory's perhaps unfair advantage it achieved 506,000 hours of tendered work over six years while seeking 5.5 million man hours of work. I put it to honourable senators that it is hardly inhibited in terms of its capacity to seek commercial work by tender. To me it shows gross incompetence in attracting work, notwithstanding that there may have been some sort of duplication. I make no judgment as to where the responsibility lies. Quite clearly the factory has demonstrated no skill, no confidence, no capacity and no ability to attract commercial work, even given the abnormal commercial advantage it has over those companies which have to make a profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Sidchrome could not operate in that way.

—Yes. The honourable senator on my right would certainly not score at that rate. Evidence was given also by the Professional Engineers and Officers Association that the factory was not prepared to take on further commercial work because it did not want to be embarrassed in the event that it got other defence work. What I find remarkable is that it still tendered for 5.5 million hours. It has a record for the last six years of having approximately 36 per cent of 50 per cent of its capacity as a standard rate of its guaranteed defence work. There was no indication that it was likely to get more, yet it was so concerned and so embarrassed that it was terrified to tender for more than 5. 5 million hours. One has to question seriously whether that is a justifiable reason for it being so incompetent.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall turn very quickly to the social aspects which are weighing upon some parts of the community. The sale of the factory to private enterprise should not necessarily be to the social or economic detriment of the Bendigo area in the event that a private operator is likely to be more efficient, more capable, more competent and likely to maintain present defence levels. There has been a guarantee by the Government, if honourable senators care to read the evidence- not a written guarantee but certainly a guarantee that anybody could read into the--

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds nearly as good as Poseidon was a few years ago.

—Senator Walsh is as relevant as he always is to every other argument he has ever been involved in. He is so obscure, so abstract and so divorced from reality that I find some difficulty in finding something to respond to. Perhaps the private operator could maintain the present defence level and certainly he could expand considerably the commercial side of things. It ought to be recognised that at present there is considerable expansion, in terms of real dollars, of the engineering sector of the community. I suspect that any manufacturer which takes over that factory will bring along its own orders and, together with that, will attract new business. In the event that the factory does not attract a new buyer and it is subsequently wound down, naturally there will be some social and economic indications for the Bendigo district.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say all the evidence we had was given on the basis that the factory was going to close down. The doom and gloom which pervaded that area when we sought evidence was, to say the least, depressing, even to an exuberant optimist like myself. Considerable evidence was given to the Committee of the various effects that closure would have. Naturally much of it was subjective by nature. Regrettably, some of it was both emotive and inaccurate. The following is an exchange between Senator Button and Mr Curnow from the Bendigo Trades Hall Council:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 7 in the conclusion you say that in real terms nearly $ 3m is paid in wages and this in turn is channelled into the economy of Bendigo. What do you mean by real terms?

INTERJECT.PARA: It does not matter that he is $1m out, but so be it--
or so, but that would be the money that would be spent actually on a year to year basis. The balance would be in, I think, taxation accounts for some things.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —Why I ask this question is that we do not want to have to write a report in which we say that in the view of the Secretary of the Trades Hall at Bendigo, the Ordnance Factory is worth $3m to the economy of Bendigo and in view of the evidence of the workers of the factory it is worth $7m. Do you follow what I mean?

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Curnow-Yes. I worked out what a person would spend in wages in Bendigo.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —You made some calculations about that?

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Curnow-Mainly on what I spend and how I live.

I do not know whether this man has three wives, one wife, is single, has eight kids, is an alcoholic, is frugal, or what he is. All I know is that he has worked out what everyone else spends on what he spends. The Australian Bureau of Statistics was asked to comment on a survey conducted by the incumbent of the State seat that presumably covers that area. He formed a study group of some sort. The group gave much evidence on the implications of the closure. It had nothing to do with what might happen if there was a sale. The methodology was examined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which had this to say about that group's survey:

The telephone poll had no sampling technique or description of how it was considered. I would regard the results as completely unreliable. The projection of the 50 per cent response rate on to the whole population is entirely fallacious.

It went on at great lengths to describe the real danger in taking any notice whatsoever of that survey. Regrettably, that was symptomatic of every part of the social evidence that we got. Frankly, the factory, employing 650 people and with an annual Budget of $9m, is an important part of the Bendigo economy. Nobody doubts that. Naturally there will be some downturn in the real economy and in real estate if the factory is closed. There will be some unemployment among those who are employed in industries which are indirectly affected by the factory.

As must be the case, the decision as to whether those retrenched workers stay within the community at Bendigo or move on to other areas is very much a matter for themselves. However, the Government is well placed to redeploy those people in other Government factories over the next period. Of course, we ought to understand that there is a demand within the total community for the sorts of skills that are available at Bendigo at present. Of the 650 employees, 175 are guaranteed jobs because they fall within the Public Service Act; 233 fall within trades associated with the metal industry; 132 are semi-skilled workers in the same capacity; and 102 are apprentices. I would be staggered if, in this day and age of mobility and demand, those people could not get jobs, providing they are prepared to go and look for a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet you would be singing a different tune if it had been Ordnance Factory, Fremantle.

—I can only say to the honourable senator that I have lived in about four mining towns and each one has closed down. I have had or my father has had to move on to another place. We have done it graciously, willingly and in pursuit of a job. We do not believe that there is a job for anybody in any town or any place which is guaranteed forever by the Government. Evidence has been given that there are two other heavy engineering works within the Bendigo region. I conclude that as far as I am concerned the factory ought to remain open. I recommend that.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The moment the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee came down with its recommendation for the sale of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, it sounded the death knell for that factory. We are not talking about a judicial murder; we are talking about an ideological thrill kill on the part of the Government. It never really intended to sell the factory . This is just a ploy to close it down. That comes through in the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Government's Clothing and Ordnance Factories and in the attitude of the Lynch Committee, which brought down the decision. I do not think the original Lynch decision was based on very much thought. I do not think it gave very much thought to the matter. It looked around and said: 'Where can we give a palliative to certain ideological Liberals in the party? This is where it occurred. It is true that the majority report of the Committee has quite clearly gone through evidence and developed some arguments in favour of sale to private enterprise or closing it down. I do not think the Lynch decision ever considered any of those factors. The decision to close or sell the factories in Bendigo and Coburg was an ideological one, one that was meant to run brownie points in the party room.

SPEECH.PARA: One has only to look at the composition of the Committee to understand what it was about. I would have thought that the Government, reluctant though it was to set up the Committee, would appoint a couple of Victorians to it because it concerned their electorate, their base. Apparently none of the brilliant legal minds in the Liberal Party that represent Victoria could serve. Instead, we had a situation in which it said: 'Who lives the furthest from Bendigo?' The answer is Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator John Martyr. I have some sympathy for those honourable senators because they have had to carry the can for the Government. They have done it diligently. If they have done it with loyalty it is not a particular virtue for which I would criticise them. It is a particular quality in life that one does admire loyalty and they have been particularly loyal to the Government. I do believe, however, that in spite of the sincerity of their approach they had ideological blinkers on. Over the years Senator Martyr has probably had many ideological blinkers on from time to time. However, as I said before, there is no doubting his loyalty to the Government. I am not casting any aspersions on the sincerity of his approach to this matter.

At the inquiry-I was only there briefly; I admit that-and in this place Senator Crichton-Browne has shown himself to be the greatest gung ho capitalist I have ever seen. It is a pity that the calls of government have deprived the Bendigo Ordnance Factory of a natural manager who could have gone in there with enthusiasm and dynamism and restored the profits of that factory within a few months. That is very disappointing. If the electorate rejects him in five years and the factory is still there he would be most welcome. There would, of course, be a great smell of tar and feathers awaiting him.

The more interesting aspect to me as a Victorian senator has been the reaction of the Liberal Party in Victoria and the local Liberal members. Over the years they have all espoused a belief in private enterprise. They all go around warning the electorate of the threat of socialism and how bad government enterprises are. However, the moment their government does something about it they all bow out in typical loyal fashion. The Federal member for Bendigo, Mr Bourchier, went virtually on three months' holiday, going off to the United Nations, and let his electorate stew. Of course, he does not like the decision. If it had been made in any other Federal electorate, Mr Bourchier would applaud it. It is only because it has been made in his electorate that he gives lip- service in opposition to it. Only two conclusions can be drawn. Either he is insincere-one would hate to allege that about a member of parliament-or he is a pathetic local representative in terms of having some influence over government policy. They are the only conclusions I can draw about it. Mr Bourchier says he will make representations to Sir Phillip Lynch. Good luck to him. I hope he succeeds. But, given his past track record, I doubt it. Mr Bourchier issued a Press release today. It was stated in the Press release:
He made it clear that he supported the sale of the factory to private enterprise, which would run it more efficiently, but that if it could not be sold the Government should continue to operate it.
Obviously, Mr Bourchier disagrees with the decision of the Committee. Of course, he went on in typical Liberal fashion. The telex stated:
Mr Bourchier . . . complained that the trade union movement had sabotaged prospects for selling the factory by veiled threats of industrial action against any purchaser.

In a typical Liberal tactic, the Government is trying to take the heat off by attacking the trade union movement. I do not think it will get away with it. I do not think the people of Bendigo could be that gullible.
Local State members have been very active on this issue too. Mr Daryl McClure and Mr Bruce Reid were quoted in the Bendigo Advertiser on Monday. They were reported as follows:
''As far as we are concerned, there will be no closure of the Bendigo factory'' , they said.

They are the local Liberal members-note the two up for election. The Upper House member is not facing election; he will worry about a Press release in three years' time. Of course, in line with what Mr Bourchier said those State members are referred to later in the article. It states:
The two politicians said it was ''now clear that the union leadership was using its own workmates in a political game in a State election.''

I can assure honourable senators that the people who work in the ordnance factory in Bendigo do not have time for any political game; what they are interested in is retaining their jobs. Those local members, in the public relations material that they have been putting out, have said that they oppose the sale of the factory. They claimed also in press releases months ago how they had put in great submissions in order to prevent this closure. What we really have to do, of course, is to compare their four flimsy paragraph, one-page submission with the detailed submission of every other goup in Bendigo, including the three or four different levels of workers at the factory. We can look at the Council's submission. All the submissions were detailed, rational submissions. What did the two local Liberal members do? They put in a one-page submission. I wonder just how fair dinkum they are.

There has been a lot of debate on why the Ordnance Factory should be retained and why it should not. I will not go into all the defence arguments; I think Senator Siddons covered those admirably. There is a case for Australia having a reserve defence capacity. We have been caught short before. No one can gaze into a crystal ball and say when the next world war or local military action will be. It is essential that Australia retains the capacity to develop its own defence equipment. It is essential also that we do not lose our technological base. The destruction of that factory would represent the loss of a great resource for Australia.

It is true, as has been mentioned, that the factory is doing commercial work. I heard Mr Roberts's evidence and I got an entirely different impression from that of Senator Crichton-Browne. He talked about a 9 per cent success rate. What he has not developed here tonight is any indication of what the normal success rate is in tendering for commercial work through private enterprise or anywhere else. I got an impression-it could have been incorrect-that that was quite a good batting average.

Liberal governments over the years-both Federal and State-have talked about decentralisation. What they usually mean is decentralising into the suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney or they talk about it but they rarely do it. The destruction of this factory would go completely against decentralisation. I commend Senator Crichton-Browne for spending three or four minutes on the social effects the closure of the factory would have on Bendigo. I think this is an important issue . The unemployment rate in Bendigo is 10 per cent. In the nearby surrounding town of Castlemaine, a fire recently burnt out the major employer in that town. It would be disastrous for Bendigo if this factory were to close down.

I come to the point about why I do not believe the sale of the factory was ever feasible. At no stage in the evidence that I have read-I cannot deny that it is not there somewhere-was a proper investigation done as to whether there was a commercial buyer. I would have thought that the Committee should have done that. I know it is difficult. Is there a commercial buyer or is this just an excuse to close down the factory? On what basis would that commercial buyer buy the factory? Would it be just to asset strip? It is no use putting platitudes in the report that we should not sell the factory as an asset stripping exercise. Of course, someone who can see making a quick profit will do that. I do not believe that there is a commercial buyer for this factory. The only alternative left is to keep it as a government-run instrumentality. I do not believe it should be closed down. I believe the people of Bendigo have been short-changed by this decision.

I repeat my initial assertion: The original Lynch decision was baseless. it was done for ideological reasons. We often hear that the Liberal Party is a free- enterprise party in spite of the scores of tax concession schemes and in spite of regulating of industry all over the place. I think the intention of the sale of these two factories was to fob off certain dissidents in the Liberal Party who want to see a closer relationship between their philosophy and actual government. I hope that in the end we will get a consensus on this. I think it will be a major issue in the State election. I think the Government will get a message then that maybe it is not worth the ideological thrill in electoral terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise three queries in relation to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories which concerns the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Firstly, I am concerned that so little attention was devoted to the underlying reasons which caused the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo to degenerate into a situation where closure of what was once an important defence establishment in a decentralised area of Australia now appears to be necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: Experience in the conduct of similar establishments reveals, for instance, that there is too much departmental intrusion from a variety of sources in the day to day management of such industries. The factory managers are frequently subjected to numerous interferences from committees, departmental heads, sundry experts and other authorities. All too often the prospects of an overseas trip will turn purchasing officers away from Australian sources to overseas suppliers despite token support from departments on maintaining a viable defence industry in Australia. In so many areas today there is nothing short of a mania to purchase overseas rather than to acquire from Australian based sources. Until these un- Australian practices are reversed, manufacturing and employment in Australia must be in a state of vulnerability both to closure and retrenchment.

The second concern I have about the report is the lack of depth as to the reasons why the factory lacked adequate finance over the years to update sufficiently its plant and equipment to meet the needs of a modern and efficient manufacturing establishment capable of meeting the sophisticated requirements of , for example, the Department of Defence. Unless we are prepared to examine the fundamental reasons for the demise of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory then other similar establishments could well follow the fate suggested by the Committee.

Thirdly, I am not satisfied that there was adequate research to indicate that the factory was capable of being sold or kept as a continuing concern and as a viable proposition. However, I do not want the Senate to take from my remarks that a degree of rationalisation or even surgery after years of neglect is not necessary. I simply emphasise that I think we must look behind the woodwork and examine the reasons for the demise so that we can offer a constructive and not a destructive report so important to so many Bendigo families. The amendment as distributed represents a wide range of matters of condemnation of Government policy. As a package I therefore cannot accept the Opposition's amendments. On the other hand, I believe that the report has certain fundamental deficiencies that I have listed. For this reason I feel myself in a position of not being able to recommend the report as amended to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been debating yesterday and again this evening the report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on the Government Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. The Committee was set up in response to a decision by the Government in April last year in the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions to endeavour to sell the factory to private enterprise. The response to that decision from members of the Australian Labor party was quite predictable. They obviously react on doctrinaire lines by saying that anything owned by the Government should be retained by it. They reacted in this debate almost with indignation at the thought that something owned by the Government should be sold to private enterprise, without really considering the pros and cons of doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee was established to undertake the task of evaluating the Government's decision. It is very pleasing to note that the majority members of the Committee, Senator Chrichton-Browne and Senator Martyr, both of whom have spoken in this debate, have supported the decision after having heard evidence and evaluating the pros and cons of the matter. However, the Labor members of the Committee and the Australian Democrats member of it have taken the view that not only should the factory be retained but also no attempt should be made to sell it and that further, as I understand their speeches and the amendment that has been moved, the factory should be expanded as a government operation. Although I was not surprised that the Labor members of the Committee should take that view, I am rather surprised that Senator Siddons of the Australian Democrats should have taken that view.

The report of the Committee was tabled only yesterday. It is an important document of 150 pages. Obviously the matter needs to be studied much further. The decision of the Senate tonight to take note of the report will no doubt be supported by all honourable senators, and the report will be put to further study. Certainly it will be studied by the Government. In due course and, I hope , as soon as possible the Government will make a formal response to it. However, as I have said, it is interesting that the report supports the decision that was made nearly a year ago by the Government to seek to dispose of this factory to private enterprise. I might say that the Government then decided to test the interest of the private sector in acquiring the factory, but we did not pursue that test because of the interest of the Senate and the establishment of this Committee. So, any further steps to give effect to that decision of the Government have been suspended over this period. It is too early yet to say, as seems to have been assumed in this debate, that the private sector will not be interested and that there cannot be a sale of the factory. In fact, I am advised that, when the Government's decision was announced, several major companies responded to the invitation to register an interest in it. So, it may well be that this is a real proposition and it is not to be assumed that the private sector will not be interested and that a sale would not be made to it.

However, I do not propose tonight to debate the pros and cons of that decision. As I have said, it has already been considered by the Government. It has now been considered by the Committee. The Government will be considering the report of that Committee and will then be making a further decision as to what steps are to be taken. Of course, the Senate will be advised of that decision. What the Government is concerned about is that we should be making full use of available capacity. There is an excess of ordnance capacity in the two government-owned factories-the one at Maribyrnong and the one at Bendigo-and we believe more effective use could be made of these capabilities. If private ownership is interested in the factory at Bendigo, that will contribute to the rationalisation process.

The fact that a private owner may operate the factory along slightly different lines from the one that is in existence in Bendigo does not mean that we will have all the great social and economic evils that seem to be so readily seen by the Opposition. Some of the functions that the factory has may well continue. Others may be better transferred to the other operation at Maribyrnong. We see this as part of a sensible rationalisation of resources. It may well be that a private purchaser will contribute to that rationalisation, but that does not mean to say that there will be drastic social and economic effects in Bendigo. At this stage that is the course that the Government is pursuing. If the private sector in the end proves not to be interested or a sale on reasonable terms cannot be effected, the matter will be reviewed again. I make it quite clear that the Government has not made a decision to close the Factory. We have simply made a decision to endeavour to sell it to a private operator and to seek to rationalise the Government's needs for the capability, some of which is excess to what is required at present.

The real reason why I have taken part in this debate this evening is that I wish to respond, on behalf of the Government, to the amendment that has been moved to add to the motion to take note of the report that the Senate should express its concern about a number of aspects of the Government's defence procurement policies. I propose to address that amendment briefly and to invite the Senate to reject it as being quite unjustified and as inappropriate to the motion.

The amendment is in a number of parts. It speaks of a failure by the Government to respond to a number of reports of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I take that to mean two reports on this subject of defence procurement, one known as the Hamer report which I think was presented in 1977, and a much more recent one known as the Katter report which was presented in 1980. There are a number of aspects of the Hamer report of 1977 which the Government has responded to and acted upon. Many of its recommendations have been incorporated into standard departmental practices and others are in line with existing practices. However, the Katter report laid down or proposed a fairly major long term policy in relation to defence procurement over the next 10 years, and that matter is still being considered by the Government.

The next aspect of the amendment expresses the view that the Government has failed to provide modern guns and missiles for ships of the Royal Australian Navy. This is really quite an extraordinary proposition and is quite untrue. The Navy's ships are fitted with modern weapons. By way of example, the four guided missile frigates which are in the process of construction today will have the most modern 76 millimetre guns, standard anti-aircraft missiles and harpoon anti -ship missiles. These are the same weapons as those in service in the United States Navy. As I understand it, Senator Siddons was concerned that the Navy would not have guns to shoot down missiles. This is, in fact, what the 76 millimetre guns are designed to do.

The submarines are also equipped with new mark 48 torpedoes together with the latest fire control systems and other sensors. The new Fremantle class patrol craft have a gun quite adequate for their present role. I know that there has been some debate about that gun but for the purpose of the patrol vessel it is perfectly adequate. Recently one of the patrol vessels was engaged in an operation off the North Queensland coast. The armaments that it had at its disposal were quite adequate for that operation which is one of the major types of operation which these patrol vessels are called upon to engage in.

The amendment then alleges that the Government has allowed the ordnance factories to run down through lack of work while ordering weapons from overseas which could have been manufactured in those factories. This is probably the gravamen of the Labor Party's views on this whole subject supported as they are by the Australian Democrats. This raises the fundamental question as to how far we can develop, with our relatively very limited demand for weaponry compared with other nations, a capacity in Australia to meet this demand in any sensible way. We would be establishing a capability which in many cases would be far in excess of the demand that we are likely to have. A very good example is the complaint from Senator Siddons about the acquisition of the 155 millimetre gun which he said could have been manufactured in the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo. Although that may well be true, the fact is that only 36 of these guns will be required by the Australian Army in the forseeable future. I know that Senator Siddons is a businessman and I thought he would have a more businesslike approach to problems of this kind. Why would the Government establish a capability to manufacture a gun when it had a demand for only 36? This is a good example of why, from purely economic common sense, we are required, I believe, to purchase a lot of this equipment overseas even though it may be possible to manufacture it in Australia.

Of course, we are in the business of manufacturing our own defence equipment when it is economically sensible to do so. We have an offset policy which we pursue and which has created a great deal of business for Australian manufacturers. We have announced that our ability to manufacture artillery will be enhanced by the local manufacture of a 105 millimetre gun which is required for the Army. There is sufficient demand for this gun to justify fully the local manufacture. The Bendigo factory has and will have a significant share of this work.

I have given a very reasonable comparison. In one case there is long term demand for an adequate amount of equipment which justifies the development of a capability in Australia. That is being done with the 105 millimetre gun for the Army. There is, of course, concentration on the local manufacture of various forms of ammunition. I do not want to go into the details of it, but this is another example of long-running demand which justifies the establishment of a capability.

The amendment then goes on to complain about the failure to secure adequate guarantees on cost, delivery, offsets, Australian industry participation and technology transfers for defence material bought overseas. It refers particularly, as I have said, to the 155 millimetre gun. I have already mentioned why the decision was taken not to develop that capablility. The amendment also mentions the Leopard tank that ironically involved a contract entered into by the Labor Party when in government in 1975. In relation to that acquisition to date $13m in offsets has been achieved in pursuance of the policy of local manufacture where it is economically sensible and feasible.

The policy of the Government is that contracts for major defence equipment should be negotiated wherever possible to obtain the best prices, firm delivery dates and contractual commitments for Australian suppliers to provide part of the project. The policy has been in force for some years and over the last 10 years some $400m-worth of work has been undertaken by Australian industry. That policy will be pursued and no doubt as Australian industry develops further capacity much more use will be made of it. There will be a number of further opportunities for Australian industry to obtain greater opportunities in the future. Of course the decision to purchase the new tactical fighter-the largest single purchase of defence equipment that Australia has ever made-will give a tremendous boost to the Australian aerospace industry. I have already indicated that Australian industry will expand with the production for the Army of the 105 millimetre gun and its ammunition and other types of ammunition.

A number of other examples could be mentioned. I have already given many examples of the policy of encouraging local manufacture where it is economically sensible to do so. It is certainly the Government's policy to expand that manufacture as far as possible. We have regard to the need to build up rapidly our defence capability. We have to acquire weaponry of a very sophisticated and expensive kind. We have to make sure that we can acquire it quickly and make the best use of the limited financial resources we have at our disposal in doing so. Therefore, it would be quite irresponsible for a government to insist in an arbitrary and doctrinaire way on the development of equipment in Australia for limited runs at a vastly greater expense than the equipment could be obtained overseas. For all those reasons, the Government rejects the Opposition's amendment, supported as it is by the Australan Democrats, and trust, that the Senate will vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion and totally oppose the amendment. The dissenting reports and the speeches of those who have supported them, particularly this evening, have one common threat. They all vigorously contest that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory can be sold as a going concern. What supernatural prescience have people opposing this motion got that I have not? No one will knows whether the factory can be sold as a going concern until all efforts have been made to sell it. I strongly contest that they have any better knowledge than I or anybody else in the community who is interested in this matter. My firm belief is that when all efforts are made there will be a very good chance of the factory being sold but that is as much speculation as has been offered in the opposite direction by the Opposition. None of us will know until all of the efforts have been put into selling it. I know that, human nature being what it is, the task of selling the factory will not be made easier by the definite assertions in Parliament tonight and last evening that it cannot and will not be sold. Honourable senators opposite and others may denigrate the Parliament and the people in it but there is no doubt that a great deal of notice is taken of what is said in this chamber and the other one.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons took the opportunity to make a wide ranging defence statement which, with respect, I do not think added a great deal to present knowledge in the defence debate. It seemed to me that Senator Siddons linked the whole defence and foreign policy cosmos with the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. I have a vivid imagination, possibly because of the several sets of blinkers I have worn in the past or perhaps for other reasons, but my imagination is not so vivid as that I believe there may be one or two important matters in the defence, foreign affairs and ordnance situation other than the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. It is important. We thought it important enough to consider its future; but, in terms of the wide ranging situation introduced into the debate by Senator Siddons, I do not think it is relevant at all.

One memorable point Senator Siddons made was that the 4 1/2-inch and 5-inch guns presently in use-they are to be phased out soon-in our Navy are useless in modern combat. He seems to have forgotten that these guns and mounts were, for a long time and even partially now, one of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory's prime reasons for existence. It seems to me that he did not argue too strongly for retaining the factory and its facilities when he pointed out how obsolete are the things that it makes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that it should build a modern gun like the OTO-Melara, which it has a capability for and has contracted to do.

—Senator Siddons has walked around the place as I have. I concede that he has much more engineering expertise than I have. His judgment about these matters should be better than mine. But even my limited judgment and the judgment of others is that the facilities at Bendigo could not be brought to the stage to which Senator Siddons believes they could. To use a phrase I used earlier, one would need a very vivid imagination to be able to make that equation.
—Don't say we can't build anything.

—Nobody ever suggested that we could not build anything. We can do almost anything in this country but the cost is sometimes absolutely prohibitive. Senator Mason knows that as well as I do. I understand that at one stage Senator Siddons had a factory at Bendigo. If he had, it is not there now either. I suppose that the ebb and flow of economic activity affects all sorts of people and not just the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to the comments of another speaker in this debate, Senator Watson, a friend and colleague on this side of the chamber. I do not want to be unkind to him, but all the answers he seeks will be found in the report if he takes the trouble to read it. We took a great deal of trouble to put that report together so that people like Senator Watson might have the pleasure of reading it. To ask questions like he did seemed to be superfluous. I shall not spend much time with him. I shall consider the more major points raised by Senator Button, Senator Siddons and other speakers last evening and this evening. It will be seen from the report that the Committee examined the evidence in the light of various options. The Government's stated intention was to sell the OFB as a going concern. That was the option that principally occupied the Committee's attention . However, the Committee recognised that other possibilities existed for the OFB . It was for this reason that it canvassed the effects of the various options in regard to defence, commercial and social issues. I am pleased to say again that this was one set of examination points on which the Committee agreed very early. I am grateful for that. The options, other than the outright sale, discussed by the Committee were, firstly, the sale of the factory as a going concern, maintaining a partial defence capacity; secondly, rationalisation and/or closure ; and thirdly, the retention of the factory in government control. A further option raised was the sale of some parts of the OFB as going concerns in themselves. This was not an aspect on which the Committee received a great deal of evidence. We did not spend a lot of time on this option because it did not seem to be one that would be very successful in the end.

The Committee found on the evidence that the OFB possessed few totally unique industrial processes necessary to defence production. It found that most tasks at the OFB could equally be undertaken at other government factories or by industry generally. Given the low level of defence orders to the OFB in the last decade, we could not be convinced that it was abolutely vital to our defence requirements. The Committee appreciated the dilemma of the Department of Defence and the Department of Industry and Commerce in that they must attempt to obtain the greatest possible value for the taxpayers' defence dollar while, at the same time, they have to ensure that the defence skills and capabilities we already have in this country, which we have acquired at a high cost, are not lost or dissipated. To resolve the dilemma the Committee believed that rationalisation of the ordnance munitions industry was necessary and that the sale of OFB formed part of that process. The Committee believed that even an immediate closure of OFB would only marginally affect Australia's defence capacity and capability as all of those defence works at OFB could be relocated in a comparatively short time to other munitions factories.

Senator Crichton-Browne has already mentioned the difficulties of moving quickly the 4 1/2 inch gun and mounting repair facility and the difficulty of finding a building of sufficient height that would be available immediately. But I think to anyone who has the barest experience in these matters that is not an insuperable problem. We found that in order to maintain production levels OFB has had to undertake commercial work at approximately 50 per cent of production. However, as Senator Crichton-Browne pointed out, there has been only a break- even return on that commercial work. This has meant that OFB has required a subsidy each year from the defence appropriations and has been unable to resolve the problem of excess capacity. The Committee accepts the notion that that allows staff to maintain skills.

I perhaps take a more charitable view than that held by my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne because I felt the commercial work should have paid its way. The nature of the commercial work undertaken did not have the potential for an economic return to OFB as invariably it involved short run items requiring significant research and development. When the costs of running OFB are taken into account, work of this kind would appear to have made no financial contribution to the resolution of the problems of the factory. The Committee appreciated that OFB had the capacity and capability to undertake a wide range of ordnance munitions manufacture. However, the cost of tooling up for the comparatively short runs required for Australian defence orders was prohibitive compared to the cost of overseas purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —How come they can make guns for the Leopard tanks and sell them to foreign countries but our own Government is not prepared to buy them?
—Senator Siddons has already had the opportunity this evening to speak. I would have thought he would have taken that opportunity to explain that point.
—Why don't you?

—The level of commercial work undertaken at OFB casts doubts on the need for the factory as a defence establishment. In the last 10 years commercial work has accounted for approximately 50 per cent of production. Action in regard to this should have been taken as a result of past reviews of OFB's performances. That this situation has been allowed to continue since World War II is the reason why action must be taken now, we believe, to rationalise the activities of the Government ordnance factories or, alternatively, to see that they are given a real defence work load.

SPEECH.PARA: An honourable senator asked before why I did not reply on the matter concerning the Leopard tank. I think the interjection came from the Labor side of this chamber.

The Leopard tank, from memory, was ordered during the period of the Labor Government. If my recollection is correct, I think propositions were put by the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, to the then Labor Government that the turret and gun ought to be made at Bendigo. If my recollection is correct the Labor Government' s answer was no. As a commercial operation OFB has many advantages. It has a steady, skilled work force.
