Defence work should be forthcoming to the factory at least to the extent of the utilisation of unique work skills and machinery that exist at the factory at the moment as well as any additional defence contracts that might be obtained. It is hoped that a private operator will bring his own capacity and expertise to the factory.

Senator Button made a major point, I think, about the legal problems. I respect his capacity very much as a lawyer but lawyers do have different opinions. Anyway, it seems to me that the essence of his allusion to the government clothing factory case of many years ago was that provided a government factory being run under the defence power did not undertake work which exceeded 50 per cent defence work, it was then all right to take a little bit of commercial work . That puts me at odds with Senator Button's interpretation of the decision in that case. Surely what is not in contest at all here is that a government factory such as the Ordnance Factory does have a very great advantage over commercial firms when quoting for commercial work particularly when the commercial work is quoted for at rates which are far lower. The rates of man- hour return at Bendigo are far lower than the commercial rate for commercial work.

It seems to me that any government running such a factory would find itself in very serious legal trouble if it allowed that situation to continue. All of the commercial firms in competition with such a factory would want to know why they were not so favoured as was the government factory. That may only be a perceived problem but nonetheless a serious one that will be totally resolved if the sale is a success and the ordnance factory is under another kind of management. However, as I said, I cannot offer an authoritative legal opinion but the best advice we have had is that certainly there would be a problem in that direction. Also there may well be a problem in the first area I mentioned-that of a factory operating under the defence power.

We were well aware that the decision to sell OFB would cause a lot of bother locally. We were able to listen to plenty of evidence when we visited Bendigo. But Senator Crichton-Browne and I cannot see that if the decision to sell the factory is successful there will be any significant social or economic impact in the Bendigo region. I come back to where I began: I know that the whole burden of the Labor Party and Democrat case is based on the assumption that there is no hope of sale. This is bound to have some effect on potential buyers. I hope it will not. It seems to me that if the sale is successful the problem is solved to everybody's satisfaction. It is most unfortunate that the burden of the other side's case assumes there is absolutely no hope of sale, there will be an asset stripping exercise and that what the Government is trying to do is just a prelude to closure anyway. I think this is a most unfair way to go about the matter. It is quite obvious to me why this course has been chosen. With due respect to those honourable senators opposite who have taken part in the debate, I believe the proximity of the Victorian elections has a lot to do with the rather crude political grandstanding that we have seen in this chamber tonight. It has not added anything at all to the concerns of the people of Bendigo to have this matter a plaything in this chamber for the advantage of some and the disadvantage of others.

Still, the Committee had a job to do. I thank some of those honourable senators on the other side who spoke for at least giving us the credit of doing the job diligently and sincerely. We are very conscious of the problem that people feel is going to occur in Bendigo. We still insist that the decision to sell is the right one. If it works it could well provide a new kind of prosperity in the area. But we should all concentrate on trying to make the sale a success. I cannot understand why honourable senators on the other side of the chamber are taking the attitude that they are. It is not helping: They must see that.

In any case the Committee could not accept the concept-I think there are some basic differences between honourable senators on this side of the chamber and honourable senators on the other side of the chamber-that the Government has a social responsibility to maintain the factory in its present form. The factory has to be made viable in its own right. The best method of achieving this, given the size of defence orders, which are unlikely to increase, is to sell the factory as a going concern.

It is perfectly normal for the people of Bendigo to want the factory to remain open under government control and the present arrangement, which has prevailed for many years, because it offers continuity and the security of employment that many people seek from the Public Service. The factory does not make commercial judgments based on economic conditions. It is not subject to market forces. In fact it is insulated from almost every normal consideration including relevance. In some ways it has become the social and economic pillar of the Bendigo district.

I suppose it is worth while quoting from the Hansard record of the evidence given to the Committee in this case. My friend, Senator Crichton-Browne, is sitting beside me. He asked the Mayor of Bendigo, Councillor Stoltz:
Do you believe it is the inherent responsibility of the Government to maintain the factory because of the social benefits that it provides this community by way of employment.
The Mayor of Bendigo answered:
I think it is presently the responsibility of the Government. The Government has to weigh it very heavily in its consideration in selling the Ordnance Factory.
Senator Crichton-Browne asked:
Do you see the Government's responsibility as being inherent in providing the level of employment that it is providing now because of the benefits to your town.
The Mayor of Bendigo said:
Yes.
If employees in other factories experience this sort of difficulty, the worst option prevails and the factory closes.

Now there need be no long term unemployment for the present factory workers. Evidence has been given that there are two other heavy engineering works within the Bendigo region. It can reasonably be expected that they will absorb a part of the factory's activities and that any additional work load moving to them will militate in part against local unemployment and the economic effects created by total closure. Again, whilst no evidence has been given, presumably a significant number of married employees have working wives. In the event of the factory employed spouse being redeployed outside the Bendigo region, the vacancy created by his wife would provide further job opportunities to those presently unemployed. I raise these matters not because I believe the factory ultimately will be closed but because so much gloom and doom, as Senator Crichton-Browne has said, has been painted by people who seem to wish that there be a disaster in order that they might capitalise on it politically. I commend again this report to the Senate. I ask the Senate to reject the amendment moved by Senator Button.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Button's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up increases in its capital subscriptions to two international financial institutions-the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Internatinal Finance Corporation.

Honourable senators will be aware that the main function of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was established in 1947, is to provide loans on semi-commercial terms to its less developed member countries.

Up to the end of June 1981, the Bank had lent about $US68.2 billion to its member countries for projects covering all the major sectors of economic development with emphasis on the development of infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply.

Following an examination of the adequacy of the capital base of the Bank for its operations in the 1980s, the governors of the IBRD approved in January 1980 an increase in the authorised capital stock of the IBRD of approximately $US40 billion. This represents an effective doubling of the Bank's capital base and should allow it to continue to increase its operations in real terms. The increase was covered by two resolutions, one approving a general capital increase and the other an additional capital increase. Under the latter resolution each member country is entitled to a fixed number of shares. It was passed to offset an unintended reduction in the aggregate voting power of developing countries, which would otherwise result from the general capital increase.

Australia voted in favour of the resolutions authorising these capital increaes (the text of the resolutions, including the number of shares to which each member is entitled to subscribe, is set in the explanatory memorandum to this legislation). Members, including Australia, are entitled, but not obligated, to subscribe to this authorised increase.
Australia is entitled to subscribe to 6,037 shares under the general capital increase and to 250 shares under the additional capital increase, a total of 6, 287 shares, valued at $US758.43m.

Under the general capital increase, 92.5 per cent of the subscription is to remain on call with the other 7.5 per cent ($US54.62m) to be paid-in. Of the paid-in portion, 10 per cent ($US5.46m) has to be in the form of gold or U.S. dollars and the balance ($US49.16m) in Australian dollars. The latter amount ($ US44.95m at the current exhange rate) will be paid in the form of a promissory note. Subject to agreement, with the Bank, this will be encashed in approximately equal instalments over four financial years commencing 1982-83.
Under the additional capital increase, the full subscription price of the 250 shares remains on call.

The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and it plays an important role in the S.E. Asian region. This has been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the Bank's establishment. I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue this policy of support by taking up, in full, the increase in our capital subscription to which we are entitled under the two resolutions.

The International Finance Corporation, which was established in 1956 as an affiliate of the World Bank, is an international development institution established to promote the growth of productive private investment and to assist enterprises which will contribute to the economic development of its developing member countries. In addition to the direct financial assistance it provides, which may take the form of loan or equity investment, it also arranges for other investment finance, mainly from the private sector, to be made available.

Up to the end of June 1981, the Corporation had invested about $US4.1 billion in nearly 600 ventures. The syndications it has arranged are an important measure of its ability to attract private financing for the projects in which it is involved.

In view of the need to ensure that the IFC had adequate resources to continue to expand its operations, the governors of the Corporation approved a resolution in September 1977 authorising an increase in the IFC capital from $US110m to $ US650m. Australia voted in favour of the resolution. As in the case of the (IBRD ) capital increase, member countries are entitled, but not obligated, to subscribe to additional shares.

Australia is entitled under the resolution (the text of which is set out in the explanatory memorandum) to subscribe an additional 9,976 shares at a cost of $ US9.967m, all of which would be paid-in. Under the terms of that resolution all payments associated with additional subscription must be made by 1 August 1982.

The IFC has proved itself to be a very effective catalyst for attracting private capital for investment in enterprises in developing countries. DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS (PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 February, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the amendments to the Act in question, brought about by the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Amendment Bill, is to enable the privileges and immunities available under the 1963 parent Act, which basically are privileges and immunities available to persons and organisations, to be accorded to representatives of international organisations attending conferences of the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, held in Australia. To give an example, the European Economic Community now has an interest in Antarctic marine living resources. The immunities available under the present legislation would be, by this legislation, extended to such an organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second purpose of the Bill is to enable the granting of exemption from Australian income tax to foreign experts and committee members of organisations such as the Common Fund for Commodities and the Asian Development Bank when those people are visiting or working in Australia. So the first amendment, dealt with in clauses 2 to 5, relates specifically to provisions which must be made for organisations such as the EEC. I point out that when the 1963 Act was drafted it was not then contemplated, as I understand it, that international organisations as well as countries would become members of other international organisations. However, Australia has now ratified the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. Under this Convention the European Economic Community will be entitled to participate along with the member states of the Antarctic Treaty. The European Economic Community, for example, will send delegations and representatives to meetings and, as the host state, Australia has an obligation to extend to such delegations from such organisations the same privileges and immunities enjoyed by diplomatic envoys representing particular countries.

The second amendment, which is set out in clause 6, has been introduced to enable Australia to implement a taxation obligation under two international agreements. One establishes the Common Fund for Commodities; the other establishes the Asian Development Bank. This amendment will exempt from taxation on income experts participating in the work of prescribed organisations. At present Australia is not a party to any other agreement under which a similar concession could be made. I refer the Senate to the fact that in her second reading speech the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) advised:
The measures should not be significant in terms of revenue forgone.

That is to say taxation revenue, as the number of persons and organisations involved in this process of attending functions and research meetings in Australia would be few. This is very much a machinery Bill to facilitate the participation of organisations such as the EEC and others in conferences and so on in Australia subject to the same conditions as those to which diplomatic representatives of certain countries are now subject. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. Indeed it is eminently sensible, but I think we should make some points about it in passing which relate to the extent of Australia's commitment to research into and the conservation of Antarctic resources.

The Antarctic is an area in which Australia has had an extension of its national charmed life, in geographical terms at least. The lucky country ethic has extended to Australia's participation in research and development in the Antarctic region. The Antarctic has an enormous potential in terms of mineral development, for example, coal and other minerals. I suppose the extent of that potential is not accurately known at this stage. There is also a much better recognised potential in terms of the marine resources which need research and protection. Quite recently the level of Australia's commitment in the Antarctic was attacked because of Government cost-cutting measures. One of Australia's bases, Casey, is threatened with closure. It needs several million dollars in order to keep operating. The important point here is that if by 1991, when the question of the Antarctic involvement of various countries is to be reviewed, Australia has not made a better effort in relation to its presence in a vast area of the Antarctic we certainly stand to receive a great deal of criticism about the sort of efforts we have made to date.

Only last week Dr Clarrie McCue, the Director of the Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and Technology, was reported as saying that the Division could not continue its normal activities without additional resources. With respect, it is another example of short term, ad hoc decision making and an absence of any sensible long term planning approach to Australia's commitment to the Antarctic and to the development and researching of resources available in that region. I shall mention one example. The glaciological work being done at Casey is acknowledged by some experts as possibly the best in the world. It is a field in which Australia attained some degree of international prestige. If the Casey base were to close it would set back a most valuable research project. I do not think the Casey base will be allowed to close but I think it can be run down to the extent where it does not make a viable contribution to the region or does not contribute in any sense to a viable future presence for Australia in that region.

We are concerned, as I think it is appropriate for an Opposition to be concerned. I was listening to the debate earlier tonight. I was sometimes chided for putting forward views about these matters-chided in a very kindly way. The Government needs to get on with development of policies about Australia's role in the Antarctic. It is essential to get on with exploration of the potential oil and mineral rich territory before the treaty runs out in 1991. It is essential to get on with research into the marine resources of the Antarctic. It is essential to keep work such as the glaciological research being done at Casey going in a viable sort of way so that Australia can continually have a presence in that area of which we can be proud.

In 1991 there will be all sorts of conflicting claims surrounding any negotiations on a new agreement and we do not want to be in the position of having it claimed against us that we have neglected our obligations in respect of the very substantial area of the Antarctic under Australian control. The fact of the matter is that the whole future of the Antarctic is going to be a major issue once technology develops to a point where development of the Antarctic becomes feasible. Australia should be laying the groundwork now to enable it to participate fully in the debate on the future of this area. We commend the Bill to the Senate. We use this occasion to remind the Government that in this as in many other areas of policy development the performance has been less desirable than it might be. We otherwise wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -We thank the Opposition for the speedy passage which it has given to this Bill. I also thank Senator Button for the comments which he made on behalf of the Opposition. I have noted his comments with regard to support for our projects in the Antarctic. Perhaps he is aware of a statement that was made a day or two ago by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) with regard to our commitment to the Antarctic and our support for the work that is being undertaken there. I will not comment in any detail on the matters that were outlined by Senator Button but simply draw attention to that recent statement of the Minister. I thank the Senate for the speedy passage of the Bill and I commend it to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 February, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill also has a certain machinery quality about it. I would like to begin by explaining the purpose of the Bill which gives effect to a Government decision announced in a statement on 20 August 1981. The purpose enunciated in that statement is to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. The function of the Centre is to mobilise and expand Australia's research capacity so as to assist developing countries in agricultural and related areas and to develop an expanded, better co-ordinated and more identifiable Australian effort aimed at achieving nutritional self-sufficiency in developing countries. Apart from some qualifications which the Opposition has by way of amendment and so on- I hope the Government will give some consideration to the amendment and not treat it in the rubber stamp way it sometimes does-the Opposition totally applauds the initiative and spirit of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before going on to say something about its importance as we see it, I should say that a number of programs which would fall within the concept of this Bill are already being conducted by Australian agencies of one kind or another. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other bodies are doing relevant research into the topic of this Bill. The present situation in many developing countries regarding the availability of food supplies and the availability of adequate long term food supplies is a very serious one indeed. The international community has long recognised this and, in consequence, a number of agencies and programs have been established, several of which operate through the United Nations.

In Australia at the moment there is no mechanism which could promote a co- ordinated and systematic approach to Australia's agricultural aid assistance. Most aid is given on a somewhat ad hoc basis as a result of requests for help from various governments. For example, the International Rice Research Institute has relied on a number of occasions on Australian expertise and assistance supplied by an organisation such as the CSIRO. That is just one example which comes quickly to mind. By and large the aid which is given in terms of agricultural production, is, as I have said, given on an ad hoc basis. There is a need to establish an effective structure for identifying the agricultural problems of developing countries. In particular, there is no structure which operates to co-ordinate the efforts of university researchers, State departments of agriculture, the CSIRO and any private organisations and individuals. I again make the point that the work done by some of the university bodies, private organisaions and individuals, and the CSIRO is quite significant. This Bill has been introduced into the Parliament to correct some of the deficiencies caused by the fact that there is no umbrella body. It is expected that the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research will co-ordinate and make more identifiable Australia's overseas aid efforts.

I will make some brief comments on the question of the organisation of the Centre itself. The Centre is not, itself, to engage in any research activity. It will contract research work out to various bodies, such as universities, State departments and other organisations, including the CSIRO. As I said earlier, it will be an umbrella organisation which will be responsible for co-ordination. The Government has insisted that there be greater efforts to involve scientists and institutions from developing countries. This is dealt with in clause 5 of the Bill before the Senate. Clause 7 establishes the Board of Management of the Centre, which will be responsible to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for the conduct and control of the affairs of the Centre. The support services for the centre will be provided by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. There is also to be a Policy Advisory Council, which will consist of 17 ministerially appointed members from various organisations interested in research. The Board of Management of six members will consist of the President of the Policy Advisory Council, the director of the Centre, the directors of ADAB and three other members from the Policy Advisory Council. The Centre will have a director and about ten professional staff.

It is quite apparent from what I have said that the Opposition supports this Bill. Efforts by countries such as Australia in the area of overseas aid are essential if we are to contribute to a new equitable world economic order. There is a crying need to do something about the millions of people in the world today who are starving because of the inability of their countries to produce sufficient food. Australia, through the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), has taken somewhat flamboyantly noisy initatives in relation to the Brandt report and the whole question of the North-South dialogue. But when we get to the nitty-gritty in these issues, Australia's contribution has not been as good as it might be, that is to say, we have not gone to the extent which one might wish to put our money or our organisational capacity where our mouths are in relation to this question of aid for underdeveloped countries.

The legislation in that context is welcome. It would be more welcome if it were accompanied by a further commitment to Australia's foreign aid contribution, which has significantly declined in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was $100m extra in the Budget.

—Yes, I understand that. I said that it had significantly declined in recent years. Aid management in Australia needs reform and reorganisation. It needs to be streamlined. This sort of legislation is a help in obtaining that result. The initiative, as I have said, is highly welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government seems confident that the resources of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau of the Department of Foreign Affairs will be adequate to ensure the efficient functioning of the Centre for International Agricultural Research, but the resources of these two bodies have been severely strained because of government cutbacks and the activities of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. It may be that cuts in funding to these bodies will not enable adequate support services to be provided.

Why should research be contracted out? Research facilities exist in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other government instrumentalities. In our view, the Government should encourage these bodies to take up research rather than to cut back on their operations. The Government has cut back on scientific research programs overall but, in some extraordinary quid pro quo, has given research out to private bodies. There is no evidence that this will be any cheaper. We submit that it is more appropriate that research be undertaken by government departments where facilities and talent exist to do that.

The Bill contains a sunset provision-clause 43-which provides that the legislation will cease to exist effectively after 12 years from the date of commencement. That is to enable a review of the operation to take place at the end of 10 years. Depending on the outcome of that review, new legislation could be drawn up or the Centre could be allowed to lapse. In our view that is a long review period. One cannot speculate, in terms of international equity, in terms of the provision of food and so on, that that is anything but an insignificant period but, in terms of an organisation such as this, it seems to us to be a long period. A shorter length of time would be more appropriate. Accordingly I propose at the Committee stage to move an amendment which was moved in the House of Representatives that the review of the operations take place after six years. Incidentally, that is a normal period for a so-called sunset clause in the United States of America, the home of sunset clauses and everything else of that kind which excites the imagination of Australia's politicians in a derivative way. We suggest that the review of operations of the Centre should take place after six years and that there should be a cessation of the operation of the Act after eight years by virtue of the sunset clause. I will be moving an amendment to that effect.

At the end of six years some people will have served two terms on the Policy Advisory Council. I think that is important in considering when the review should take place. The terms are of three years each. At the end of six years the members will have served two terms. It seems an appropriate time to conduct a review at the same time as one is looking at fresh terms for members of the Advisory Council. The Council will comprise highly skilled people and the position with regard to the Centre should be known at the end of the six year period.

Other than those comments, we commend the Bill to the Senate. I wish only to add in that chiding sort of way that we hope that in looking at the functions of this Centre the Australian Government will perhaps give some attention to the question of land reform as well as agricultural development in the countries which are the likely beneficiaries of this initiative. Otherwise I commend the Bill to the Senate.

MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS
Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600 76/77734
TR/LC:MP
9 February 1982 Senator G. T. McLaren
6 Third Street
MURRAY BRIDGE SA 5253
Dear Senator McLaren
I refer to the matter you raised in debate in Parliament on 12 November 1981 regarding Canadian nationals who are issued with visitor's visas to come to Australia and are also given work permits.

I have provided these brief notes in order to clarify the Australian/Canadian situation your raised. TALK.START.PARA: —The other matter which I raised also on the same day during the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82 concerned the VIP manifest which is tabled in the Parliament twice a year. But, buried in the appropriations for the Department of Defence is another set of costs for the same purpose, that is, flying Ministers and the Prime Minister. I have suggested before-and I suggest again-that all these costs ought to be accumulated and put before the Parliament in one paper so that we can ascertain what it costs a year for the Prime Minister, his Ministers and members of standing committees of the Senate and joint parliamentary committees to fly around this country or overseas so we are not running from one Estimates committee to another trying to define the actual cost to the taxpayer for running VIP aircraft and related costs which are charged against various departments. All these costs are split up. This is a fancy way of doing it if one wants to hide these facts from the taxpayer.

Of course, we know that that has been the practice in the last six years. Many of the costs of the Prime Minister and particularly the people who travel with him are allocated to the various departments. We are unable to get the actual costs of the present Prime Minister not only to fly around Australia but also to fly overseas. This Prime Minister, from the exercise we have been able to do, is costing the Australian taxpayer much more money. Exceptions to the general policy are made if an eligible applicant is a blinded or totally and permanently incapacitated veteran or the terms of the mortgage are onerous and causing serious financial hardship.

In assessing applications for loans to discharge mortgages on the ground of hardship the Corporation takes into account the relationship of the interest rate to contemporary market rates, the ratio of repayments to income at the time the mortgage was arranged and at the time of the application and the applicant's future income prospects.

(b) reliable estimates cannot be given of the extra finance that would be needed annually if restrictions on the grant of loans to discharge mortgages were removed. A survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1979 indicated that some 428,000 eligible ex-servicemen and women and 117,000 widows had not applied for a loan. The survey excluded serving members of the Defence Force, many of whom are also eligible persons. A significant proportion of eligible people who have a housing mortgage could be expected to seek a Defence Service Homes loan which attracts concessional interest rates if loans were freely granted. To put the potential cost into perspective, for every 100 loans at $25,000 that are granted, funds totalling $2.5m are required.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which countries have ratified the 1979 Internatinal Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women (see House of Representatives Hansard, dated 24 February 1981, page 46, Question No. 1)
(2) What reservations and/or declarations have federal states lodged with their ratifications.
(3) When will the convention enter into force.
(4) What is the timetable for Australia's ratification of the convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following countries have ratified or acceded to the 1979 International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women:

Barbados, Bhutan, Burundi, Byelorussia SSR, Canada, Cape Verde, China, Cuba, Dominica, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Ethiopia, German Democratic Republic, Guyana, Haiti, Hungary, Lao PR, Mexico, Mongolia, Nicaragua, Norway, Panama, Philippines, Poland, Portugal, Rwanda, Sri Lanka, St Vincent and the Grenadines , Sweden, Ukraine SSR, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics Uuruguay.
(2) The following reservations and/or declarations have been lodged by federal states at the time of depositing their instruments of ratification:
CANADA

Statement-'The Government of Canada states that the competent legislative authorities within Canada have addressed the concept of equal pay referred to in article 11 (1) (d) by legislation which requires the establishment of rates of remuneration without discrimination on the basis of sex. The competent legislative authorities within Canada will continue to implement the object and purpose of article 11 (1) (d) and to that end have developed, and where appropriate will continue to develop, additional legislative and other measures .'
MEXICO

Declaration-'(translation) In signing ad referendum the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which the General Assembly opened for signature by States on 18 December 1979, the Government of the United Mexican States wishes to place on record that it is doing so on the understanding that the provisions of the said Convention, which agree in all essentials with the provisions of Mexican Legislation, will be applied in Mexico in accordance with the modalities and procedures prescribed by Mexican legislation and that the granting of material benefits in pursuance of the Convention will be as generous as the resources available to the Mexican State permit.'
UNION OF SOVIET SOCIALIST REPUBLICS

Reservation-'(translation) In accordance with article 29, paragraph 2, of the Convention, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics declares that it does not consider itself bound by the provisions of article 29, paragraph 1, of the Convention, which provides that any dispute between two or more States Parties concerning the interpretation or application of the present Convention which is not settled by negotiation shall, at the request of one of them, be submitted to arbitration or to the International Court of Justice, and that for such dispute to be submitted to arbitration or to the International Court of Justice in every case there must be agreement between all the parties involved in the dispute.'
(3) The Convention, which requires the ratification or accession of 20 States Parties to come into effect, entered into force on 3 September 1981.

(4) The Convention is being examined in detail by the Commonwealth and states through the medium of the meeting of Ministers on Human Rights. To date no decisions have been reached as to the basis upon which Australia might ratify the Convention, although a good deal of progress has been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard page 558) Senator Macklin asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services inform the Senate whether the Commonwealth Government bookshops which the Government is planning to lease to private operators are currently making a profit? Secondly, will the leasing arrangements which the Government proposes include profit sharing with the Commonwealth? Thirdly, will the terms of the lease ensure the continuation of a retail shop front point of sale for all Commonwealth publications? Fourthly, will the Government ensure that all public servants employed in the bookshops have the opportunity to continue in the Public Service with the status and promotional opportunities that they currently enjoy?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Precise figures showing the profitability of individual bookshops are not available as, for accounting purposes, the transactions of all seven shops and the central mail order service are treated as one business. In recent years the overall financial result has been approximately a break-even, that is costs incurred have been recovered through sales revenue.

Notional accounts for individual bookshops compiled in 1978 for the Joint Committee on Publications Review of the Australian Government Publishing Service showed that, while the Canberra bookshop was operating profitably in 1977-78, the other six shops were then unprofitable. The figures were quoted in the Committee's Sixth Special Report, pp. 62-63.

Further notional accounts taken out recently in respect of the financial year 1980-81 indicate that Melbourne and Sydney bookshops are now operating profitably, Canberra is very close to break-even but the other four still show losses.

Interested parties are being invited to bid competitively for the right to take over the bookshops as going concerns with an established clientele. The precise nature and extent of payments to be made to the Commonwealth in connection with the proposed leases will not be known until all offers have been received and considered.

Interested parties are being informed that the Government would prefer that lessees continue to operate the bookshops from existing premises, retaining them as established and recognisable sources of government publications, unless it can be demonstrated that relocation would increase sales or customer convenience.

It is expected that some applicants for leases will seek to retain the experience and skills of staff currently employed in the bookshops by making offers of continued employment. Should any officers not be accommodated in this way, efforts will be made to place them elsewhere in the Public Service in accordance with the procedures laid down.
